excerpts: mmmm sarap & longsilog.
longsilog.author: Ryan M.
longsilog.review:
The Owner:
Manny salamat for continuing the establishment of Tess to Kusina Ni Tess. Manny such a humbled individual with awesome workers. Great conversation in tagalog although you can hear my english accent I can still have a whole conversation.

The Food:
Thank God theres filipino food in the area of downtown/tl. I have been going here for the last 2-3  years. I just learned they have a different food menu day to day. Also by going on their renewed website KusinaNiTess.com you can see what they will be serving. You have the two main breakfast dishes silogs tocilog/longsilo. Today I had the bistek na bangus (boneless) mmmm sarap & longsilog. One of my favorite dishes is laing & bopis. Theres is plenty of food and dessert to choose from here. My friends said their Kare Kare was hella good too. I am looking forward to get some Kare Kare from here.

Filipinos:
A1 Treatment & knowledgeable to help you understand what food they cooked. You wont know how it tastes til you try it. Filipino's from all over come here as well as Filipino Artists, Actors & Actresses, from the Philippines & so forth. Holla at a filipino friend so they can tell you whats really good or you can ask me. Follow hashtag or #A1LifestyleSarap
#sarapcity (Forever)

excerpts: Longsilog, garlic rice with an extra fried egg, and a side of lumpia.
Extra vinegar on the side please.
longsilog.author: Jessica F.
longsilog.review:
Yum yum yum yum yum!!!  I crave my mom's home cooking all the time and Kusina Ni Tess totally hits the spot and satisfies my need for some authentic and delicious Filipino food.

It's not in the best location (borderline Tenderloin) and it's definitely a little hole in the wall kind of spot, but it's well worth the walk to go grab lunch takeout.  I always over order because all the food makes me so happy that I wish I could eat pounds of it.  I always order breakfast for lunch and then order pork adobo to save and eat for dinner.  Longsilog, garlic rice with an extra fried egg, and a side of lumpia.  Extra vinegar on the side please.  I'm drooling while I type this and now need to plan my next visit. 

Overall- great food, prices, and people.

excerpts: I mean...what more can I say about this place except DO NOT ORDER THE LONGSILOG, tocilog or skewers.
Just because it's soooooo bomb
I don't want them to run out
longsilog.author: Anjoleen S.
longsilog.review: I mean...what more can I say about this place except DO NOT ORDER THE LONGSILOG, tocilog or skewers. Just because it's soooooo bomb I don't want them to run out

excerpts: Boyfriend got the typical LONGSILOG (marinated pork sausage with garlic friend rice and egg), a true diehard and
longsilog.author: Shela D.
longsilog.review:
Ordered the LAING (Taro leaves with coconut milk) and the DINIGUAN (pork blood stew) and it was delicious! Boyfriend got the typical LONGSILOG (marinated pork sausage with garlic friend rice and egg), a true diehard and fan-- haha, friends tried the TOCILOG (marinated pork with garlic friend rice and egg) and the PAKSIW NA TAPA (pork leg, knuckles) and the CHICKEN ADOBO (chicken cooked with soy sauce and vinegar). 

We all left super satisfied and bellies full of delicious food! -- May I add, I've been eating Filipino food all my life, and after 28 years, I think I know what "authentic" Filipino food taste like.

The staff is super friendly and once I started speaking Tagalog, she started called me "iha" which means little daughter. 

Definitely a hidden gem inside of civic center. A lot of their food is pre-cooked so you can order and be on your way! Highly recommend if you're looking for authentic Filipino food!

excerpts: Bansilog and all other silogs can satisfy your Filipino food craving.
bansilog.author: Mae N.
bansilog.review:
We found this on yelp while looking for breakfast options. We were craving for home cooked food. This did not fail! 

Serving size is big with a huge scoop of garlic rice.
Bansilog and all other silogs can satisfy your Filipino food craving.

Service is very good. They were very friendly. 

We got a bit scared when we ate at night time around 6:30 - 7 pm as someone was pushing the door to get in when they already closed for further walkins. The street is not so friendly at night. You may want to visit this place while the sun is out.

excerpts: the Longansilog and Tosilog egg was cooked well.
The Garlic fried rice like others have said tasted stale.
Way to hard and dry.
Should have just gotten steam rice instead with the silogs.
tosilog.author: Jay H.
tosilog.review: Most the food is good got the Longansilog and Tosilog egg was cooked well.  The Garlic fried rice like others have said tasted stale.  Way to hard and dry.  Should have just gotten steam rice instead with the silogs.  Also got my delivery order wrong gave me pork adobo instead of what I ordered chicken adobo.  Would eat here again with a few adjustments on what to order.

excerpts: Most of the things I tried were really good, but I stuck to ordering their most popular items, which were the tapsilog and cornsilog.
Both were flavorful but not overly salty.
Having a bite of the meat with the garlic rice, and egg was mouth-watering combination.
Aside from those two dishes, I got an order of the lumpia.
Since they were taken out of the freezer, I'm not sure if they were made in house or not, but they were still tasty.
cornsilog.author: Lucinda H.
cornsilog.review:
When I first stepped into the restaurant, I was happily greeted by one of the ladies behind the counter. She was so nice. She asked if it was my first time coming here. Since I said yes, she started explaining some of the dishes and gave me tons of samples. Either she was really enthusiastic about what they serve, or she was hoping that I would buy a lot. Either way, I got samples. That really helped in deciding what I wanted to order. 

Most of the things I tried were really good, but I stuck to ordering their most popular items, which were the tapsilog and cornsilog. Both were flavorful but not overly salty. Having a bite of the meat with the garlic rice, and egg was mouth-watering combination. Aside from those two dishes, I got an order of the lumpia. Since they were taken out of the freezer, I'm not sure if they were made in house or not, but they were still tasty. They could use a little more meat inside them though. 

When I was done ordering, the same lady that gave me samples helped me checkout. Continuing on with the good service, she sent me off with my food while addressing me by name. How nice. That kind of service (plus the good food) would be a reason for me to want to come back to this place.

excerpts: Their cornsilog was amazing!
I was going to take a picture, but ended up eating it all, so
no pic for now.
Do not let the bare decor discourage you as it is not the prettiest, but the food is amazing and the service is great.
cornsilog.author: Sherry H.
cornsilog.review: If you are looked nag for great Filipino food, this is your place.  This no frills restaurant serves AMAZING fare at a reasonable price.  They serve breakfast all day.  Their cornsilog was amazing!  I was going to take a picture, but ended up eating it all, so no pic for now.  Do not let the bare decor discourage you as it is not the prettiest, but the food is amazing and the service is great.

Ordered cornsilog and lechon kawali. 

Just the prices are a little pricy end up paying 19.85 for cornsilog, lechon kawali and calamansi juice.

excerpts: Manoksilog, pork sinigang, ?
sauteed taro leaves with coconut milk, and sisig.
All were good but we both loved the sinigang and taro leaves.
Would recommend.
manoksilog.author: Daniel H.
manoksilog.review: Very friendly staff. Food was very good. Girlfriend is Filipina and was impressed as well. We tried an array of foods: Manoksilog, pork sinigang, ?sauteed taro leaves with coconut milk, and sisig. All were good but we both loved the sinigang and taro leaves. Would recommend.

excerpts: Outstanding breakfast - lumpiasilog - fried egg, garlic fried rice , plus six lumpia (pork egg rolls)!
Manila street food , excellent taste & quality.
Very near to union square and across the street from the Hilton
lumpiasilog.author: Lisa B.
lumpiasilog.review: Outstanding breakfast - lumpiasilog - fried egg, garlic fried rice , plus six lumpia (pork egg rolls)! Manila street food , excellent taste & quality. Very near to union square and across the street from the Hilton

excerpts: Personal favorites: fried eggplant, bbq, corned beef, embotido, daing (veggie?).
Very nice staff and service.
embotido.author: Vol T.
embotido.review: I'm still a regular after all these years. And yes it's still all good. Maybe even better! Personal favorites: fried eggplant, bbq, corned beef, embotido, daing (veggie?). Very nice staff and service.

excerpts: Deep fried tilapia (with rice).
Now, if you don't know how to eat fish with bones, don't get this because you get the whole she-bang (eyes, tail, and all!).
fried tilapia.author: Sheryl D.
fried tilapia.review:
Kusina Ni Tess is across the street from the Hilton and the next block over from Parc55. Despite a couple days of going back and forth repeatedly between the two hotels (to attend a conference) I didn't even see the restaurant. It's this tiny hole-in-the-wall that I only noticed while looking out the window at the Hilton during a break between sessions. But, my god, did I love this place so much that I had lunch here 3 times over a 4-day period. This joint is what I desperately needed after traveling and eating meals of anything but Filipino food.

First meal: Lechon kawali (with rice). They offered Mang Tomas to go with it, and which I regret not getting. I got very fatty pieces with very little meat. But they served it hot-hot which I liked. Wasn't totally impressed but I decided to return and give them another try.

Second meal: Deep fried tilapia (with rice). Now, if you don't know how to eat fish with bones, don't get this because you get the whole she-bang (eyes, tail, and all!). Setting that technicality aside, it was, again, served hot-hot and it hit the spot (especially with the soy sauce).

Third meal: Adobo and mechado (with rice). Solid adobo. Mechado not so good, but decent.

The two ladies that work the register and counter were super patient. I will be back!!!

excerpts: Chicken and pork adobo, fried tilapia fish, dinaguan ("chocolate meat"), calderada (beef, ox-tail), chicken tinola (soup), sinigang na baboy (pork) or isda (fish) to name a few of the main dishes.
The menu varies from day to day, but they often have 6-8 mains to choose from.
Lumpia is sometimes on the menu, and WE ALL LOVE LUMPIA!!
fried tilapia.author: Barbie D.
fried tilapia.review:
Tes's Kitchen is definitely a hidden gem on the outskirts of the TL. Having worked in the Union Square area and now downtown, this is the closest you're going to get to authentic Filipino food where you don't have to venture too deep into cracky territory.

Chicken and pork adobo, fried tilapia fish, dinaguan ("chocolate meat"), calderada (beef, ox-tail), chicken tinola (soup), sinigang na baboy (pork) or isda (fish) to name a few of the main dishes. The menu varies from day to day, but they often have 6-8 mains to choose from. Lumpia is sometimes on the menu, and WE ALL LOVE LUMPIA!! Just today they had freshly made turon (fried wrapped banana, glazed with sticky sugar)....Scrumptious!! You can get a huge plate of rice and a main dish for $6 even. Add turon or lumpia for another $1, or a tall cocounut or cantelope juice for $1-1.50, for a total of less than $9! That's a deal.

Although Tes' Kitchen may not have the expansive selection as the more commercial restaurants like Goldilocks (closest one is in the Excelsior District) or your nearby Jolli Bee's (McDonald's of the Philippines), but this place is simple, more local, and in my opinion authentic.

It's a small hole in the wall, so it doesn't fit many. Customers are your usual nearby workers from adjacent hotels or local community members. Don't expect ambiance either, you can get that in a ritzy hotel restaurant by the Square. But they do speak ENGLISH for all you non-fluent Tagalog speakers like me.

Hours?? I don't know, I've only come here for lunch the past few years. Whenever I get that crave, and mom's place is too far for lunch, I come to Auntie Tes'.

excerpts: They even have turon (which I came back for 2 days in a row).
turon.author: Jay Z.
turon.review:
Was in town for a conference for a few days and was delighted to find a filipino joint right behind my hotel (Hilton).

My coworkers and I stopped for lunch on a Tuesday. Place had a large variety to select from, and the sweet ladies behind the counter gave out free samples.

We were specifically looking for bistek, but they didn't have it. The next best thing was a tocilog plate, which was pretty good.  They're generous with the portion and not skimpy on  the meat. They even have turon (which I came back for 2 days in a row). 

It's open early (7 am), but closes at 5 pm. I don't blame them since it's not in the best area.   Inside seating can get a little cramped.  If I find an excuse to come back, I'd order to go and eat in my room.

excerpts: The turon is crisp and chewy.
turon.author: Lauren A.
turon.review: Probably the most wholesome place I've been to. Manny is literally the SWEETEST and let us try everything before ordering. Everything is freshly cooked and I highly recommend everything haha. Garlic rice is tender and flavorful. The turon is crisp and chewy. The  pork adobo is literally God sent.

excerpts: I also had Turon for dessert
but it was served cold.
They don't have something to keep things warm.
I was expecting it would something special in it like Langka or something.
But it was just plain banana and not even very ripe one.
turon.author: Frances D.
turon.review:
It was my first time here and I had dinuguan which is one of my favorite Filipino dishes. They reheated the dish in microwave; not how I would prefer for a blood dish as the oil and blood separates because of too much heat. They didn't have a combo option so I had to order and pay for each item individually as opposed to getting some discount for a combo. The dinuguan didn't taste great either.

I also had Turon for dessert but it was served cold. They don't have something to keep things warm. I was expecting it would something special in it like Langka or something. But it was just plain banana and not even very ripe one. Not something I would pay for $1.50

And worst of all, I vomitted that night. I knew it was their dish because I didn't eat anything else new other that.

It was not a good experience and I will not go here again.

excerpts: Got turon or fried banana.
Was pleased with it especially since they added jackfruit in it.
Would come back again.
turon.author: Max W.
turon.review: Really good food. I've been craving Filipino food for a while and was glad I came here. It is kalenderia style with some short order. I was really pleased with selection of foods. I got sinigang pork and was transported back to the Philippines. It wasn't too sour. I also ordered the Laing was happy with that. My wife got chicken adobo which was tasty as well. Got turon or fried banana. Was pleased with it especially since they added jackfruit in it. Would come back again.

excerpts: The turon and halo-halo so good and great portions compared to other Filipino restaurants.
I grew up in a town that has a military base nearby and this white girl was introduced to every Filipino dish and yes I do eat dinugaun
and they have it here.
SF is lacking with Filipino food
and I'm so happy I can stop bugging my Aunties to make me food.
turon.author: Sarah T.
turon.review: It's a hole in the wall and I usually do take out. My favorite Filipino food in SF. Keep in mind I said SF, everyone always says, Daily City but I'm not in Daily City, I'm in SF. There is a daily menu and I try and go when they're serving afritada. The turon and halo-halo so good and great portions compared to other Filipino restaurants. I grew up in a town that has a military base nearby and this white girl was introduced to every Filipino dish and yes I do eat dinugaun and they have it here. SF is lacking with Filipino food and I'm so happy I can stop bugging my Aunties to make me food.

excerpts: Good turon, laing (sp?) and by request, they will make fried adobo.
turon.author: Kris I.
turon.review:
The fam wanted Filipino food, so I yelped the closet thing to Union Square and found this. The area is a little sketch, street parking only, and place is pretty hole-in-the-wall-ish. My dad is a hard man to please, but holy shit, after we started eating, he was content.

The food here is pretty legit to homecooking. Good turon, laing (sp?) and by request, they will make fried adobo. Yes, I said it, FRIED adobo.

Boo on them being out of sinigang when we went on a cold and rainy Saturday. And their lumpia isn't handmade. Also, cash only. But it's definitely still worth a visit for some legit food.

excerpts: I probably go there once every few months and they always have a good variety: laing, adobo, sinigang, corned beef, fried fish, turon, bibingka, kare kare and some others are usually on rotation.
turon.author: HM N.
turon.review: Seems like Kusina ni Tess has gotten better over the years since I first tried them. They've gone through a couple of updates/renovations (as far as I've noticed). Their space is bigger now, still a small place, but they have more tables and chairs where people can sit. Their food selection also seems to have expanded. I probably go there once every few months and they always have a good variety: laing, adobo, sinigang, corned beef, fried fish, turon, bibingka, kare kare and some others are usually on rotation. Their pork sinigang is so good! Not greasy, well-flavored and has balanced portions of meat and veggies. They now accept credit cards too but I usually pay with cash.

excerpts: Pork BBQ, Turon, Chicharrone all very good.
This place is solid!
Super Sarap!
Sarap talaga ag mga binibenta nila dito.
turon.author: Geordie E.
turon.review:
Pork BBQ, Turon, Chicharrone all very good.
This place is solid! Super Sarap!
Sarap talaga ag mga binibenta nila dito.

excerpts: I also ordered Turon (fried Plaintain) and that was a great move!
I only spent $7.20 including taxes, and with that amount of money, I already had a full meal and a dessert.
turon.author: Rochelle B.
turon.review:
I love this place! I had to go to the Philippine Consulate yesterday, and since I was starving after, I was pleased to find out that this Filipino restaurant was just a few minutes away from it.

It's definitely a Mom & Pop kind of restaurant. Small space, but owners were willing to ask people if they'd be willing to share tables with others, which was very nice of them! I ordered Kare-Kare, and I realized how much I missed it! They definitely cooked an authentic Kare-Kare. I also ordered Turon (fried Plaintain) and that was a great move! I only spent $7.20 including taxes, and with that amount of money, I already had a full meal and a dessert. Definitely worth it!

I'm coming back for sure! In fact, I'm already thinking of coming back today if I'm not too lazy to make the 20-minute walk to the restaurant from my work :)

excerpts: Turon (saba banana with jackfruit wrapped in lumpia wrapper) was pretty good, glad they didn't skimp on the langka, though I prefer less sugar when they fry it up.
turon.author: Hanneke F.
turon.review:
FOOD:  Authentic?  Yes.  As in, I could've sworn my own Lola was the one stirring up that coconuty-goodness of Laing (taro leaves with coconut milk, and little baby shrimp.)  The pusit (squid), also prepped the way I ate it as a young girl.  The adobo was decent, a little oily for my taste.  But it's too tall an order to top my Mom's, where the chicken gets so tender it falls off the bone, then you toss it on a pan to get a nice mix of tender and crispy.  (Though, Dad, you've somehow tweaked your timpla of adobo and cooking style, that the difference is nearly imperceptible.)  Turon (saba banana with jackfruit wrapped in lumpia wrapper) was pretty good, glad they didn't skimp on the langka, though I prefer less sugar when they fry it up.

SERVICE:  There's a counter up front where you order, then you seat yourself at the line of small tables along the side.  Aaaalmost like a stand at Market-Market, just in the Tenderloin.  The people are friendly, and there's a mix of people eating there.

PRICE:  Great!

Salamat Tita Tess, and I'll be back!

excerpts: Turon!
I always buy at least 4 or 5 to bring some home for my mom.
One time they didn't have any left, but the lady was nice enough to make a new batch for me when i promised to buy 6 of them!
turon.author: Le T.
turon.review: Turon! I always buy at least 4 or 5 to bring some home for my mom. One time they didn't have any left, but the lady was nice enough to make a new batch for me when i promised to buy 6 of them!

excerpts: You can see me walking around downtown, turon in hand.
turon.author: Devy E.
turon.review: When I can't make it to either my aunt's house or Daly City for my Pinoy food fix, I come here. The service is wonderful - the owners are very nice and offer taste tests of what's being offered that day. The food is pretty good as well - their lumpia and kare kare are delicious. There's not a lot of room here to have a sit down meal so I suggest getting take out and eating at Yerba Buena Gardens or anywhere outside. You can see me walking around downtown, turon in hand.

excerpts: Then there's dessert of turon and bibingka-togo as we could no longer eat them on the spot.
Seating is limited, but lucky for us we got there at 1pm.
I would go there again when I go to the city.
turon.author: maria j.
turon.review: This is a little Filipino hole in the wall restaurant with authentic tasting food, cheap too, no frills.  Reminds me of old karinderya near university belt, a bit of nostalgia. Turo turo style, so all the food is there to be seen and you get to decide based on how it looks.  Rice is plentiful, with clear broth for the asking. Then there's dessert of turon and bibingka-togo as we could no longer eat them on the spot.  Seating is limited, but lucky for us we got there at 1pm.  I would go there again when I go to the city.

excerpts: The only complaint about this place I have is they don't serve Leche Flan daily.
Their flan is freaking delicious with just the right consistency.
Bibinka is good too
leche flan.author: deryck s.
leche flan.review:
Loganisa breakfast this morning was great and a steal at $4 and they were curious with my request for some fresh garlic for my sucat (vinegar)

The only complaint about this place I have is they don't serve Leche Flan daily.  Their flan is freaking delicious with just the right consistency.  Bibinka is good too but I just wish they had some pineapple in it.

I need to come back and get some mechado, looks and smells great!

excerpts: We got their veggie lumpia, their fried milk fish, and their pork lumpia.
The fried fish was by far the best, and was absolutely delicious!
Everything was fried fresh for us, and the ladies were extremely helpful.
Would definitely recommend!
veggie lumpia.author: Kezia L.
veggie lumpia.review: My husband and I were looking for a place close to our hotel, and something that was relatively cheap. We got their veggie lumpia, their fried milk fish, and their pork lumpia. The fried fish was by far the best, and was absolutely delicious! Everything was fried fresh for us, and the ladies were extremely helpful. Would definitely recommend!

excerpts: Chicken Adobo - Always a safe choice and a Filipino staple.

This was delish
Pork Sinigang-

Also very tasty and flavorful
Beef Stew- Was the least fave and was a little too salty for my liking
chicken adobo.author: Rod M.
chicken adobo.review:
Everybody go: Hotel, motel, holiday inn
You see, If you're walking down Ellis street better take a friend
Your boy likes Filipino food what can I say
Pancit n lumpia even Kare-Kare
Workin at KNT is Lola and Lolo no need to pout
Kusina Ni Tess is making food with love to stock the house
..........................................................................................................
If you like my reviews...give me a follow.

Super cool spot in the Ellis as other's have mentioned best to keep your eyes peeled in this neighborhood but that's any big city location right? 

Buffet, Chinese Fast food buffet-style set-up. They have a huge menu that lists all of their items for sale but be WARNED not everything is available that day.  I had my heart set on pork sisig which I love ...but it's only available on Tuesday and Friday's (sad face). 

So I went with (from fave to least fave)
Chicken Adobo - Always a safe choice and a Filipino staple. This was delish
Pork Sinigang- Also very tasty and flavorful
Beef Stew- Was the least fave and was a little too salty for my liking and I probably wouldn't get again and would replace with Pork Sisig! 

Super friendly service. They have a small , medium and large to-go options which range in price from like $7-$15 I wanna say. 

The venue itself is not that big so the start of the line is near the entrance/exit of the restaurant so it makes things kind of cramped near that area. 

Suggestion to the owners would be to list what foods are available and not available THAT DAY so people don't get their hopes up. A small touch but it leaves a positive taste in people's eyes.

All in all, a solid venue for Filipino home style cooking.

excerpts: it's cooked with care and love the beef tapas or chicken adobo but the have the SECOND best Lumpia in San Francisco that's definitely five stars man
delicious food
every bite will excite your taste bud
an always get the garlic rice if it's not sold out bomb!!!!!
I'll post pictures my next trip if I could give them six starts
I would!!!!
chicken adobo.author: Rolin S.
chicken adobo.review:
Best Filipino food in this part of San Francisco
They have the soul food of Filipino food here it's cooked with care and love the beef tapas or chicken adobo but the have the SECOND best Lumpia in San Francisco that's definitely five stars man delicious food every bite will excite your taste bud an always get the garlic rice if it's not sold out bomb!!!!! I'll post pictures my next trip if I could give them six starts I would!!!!

excerpts:
* CHICKEN ADOBO ($5.50, small)
Kind of reminded me of a Chinese chicken dish, but much more acidic.
A little heavy on the salt.
Chicken was fatty with lots of skin and a little on the dry side
chicken adobo.author: Jessie L.
chicken adobo.review:
TLDR - cheap, quick, homey, hole-in-the-wall Filipino food

4 stars for the service and prices, but the food itself was at best an average 3 stars for me. 

This was my first time having Filipino food so maybe I'm just not a fan of Filipino food in general. I can't pretend I know what good Filipino food tastes like, so I can't vouch for its authenticity. It tastes very homey though, as if I were eating a home cooked meal with my parents. Filipino food seems to be all about heartiness so don't expect to find anything healthy here. Even any sort of vegetables are scarce, with food centering around meat.

Food is ordered a la carte here, cafeteria style. If you're not familiar with Filipino food, you can just point at whatever looks appealing to you behind the glass. I had no idea what anything was, so I ended up pointing and asking what everything was. The lady helping me asked if it was my first time there, and when I said yes, she was kind enough to give me small samples of her favorite dishes to try.

Prices vary depending on the type of protein/dish, averaging about $6 for small, $10 for medium and $13 for large sizes. Rice is $1.25. You can easily get a pretty filling lunch here for less than $10 with a small entree and rice.

I went with 2 small entrees and no rice:

* KARE KARE ($5.50, small)
Pork (knuckle I think?) in a peanut-based broth. The meat was a tad try, and the small size came with only 1 piece. I was expecting the broth to be thicker, but it was pretty thin and light in flavor. Served with fish paste on the side, which added a lot of saltiness, but I actually liked it without the fish paste

* CHICKEN ADOBO ($5.50, small)
Kind of reminded me of a Chinese chicken dish, but much more acidic. A little heavy on the salt. Chicken was fatty with lots of skin and a little on the dry side

excerpts: I ended up with Chicken Adobo, the mung beans stew (mongo), a stewed pork (i think it was binagoongan) ... and taro leaves in coconut milk - all in small sizes - along in with a side of rice.
so so so yummy.
For ME, everything hit the spot and took me 'home' to my childhood.
I was pleasantly surprised at the flavours and quality.
Perhaps it was because I was hungry, perhaps because it was just that good.
chicken adobo.author: Leslie R.
chicken adobo.review:
So I was at the Hilton and wanted a quick bite, and found that Kusina Ni Tess was right across the street!!  I wanted a quick meal, so I went through Eat24, placed an order for pick-up and waited a bit.  I guess I should have looked at the photos, to better understand that it's essentially a steam plate restaurant so it wasn't necessary to do that.   Anyway - when I got there, they didn't receive the Eat24 order, talked about how they don't get the order, but that it would be on Maria's cell phone, etc etc.  Also more importantly, of the 4 things I ordered and paid for, 2 of the items were not available that day - which, again - had I looked, is totally understandable when knowing it's a steam plate / to go type of place.

Rather than go through the process of calling Maria and deal with the order, I showed them my receipt, and then I was able to substitute items to make up the same totals.   The ladies in there were super accommodating and helpful (even though I was a bit disappointed that I cldn't have 2 items I had been craving on my walk over).  Luckily I'm a glutton, and love to eat - so there were plenty of other options.  

While not filipina myself, I grew up in Asia, and had home cooking at home often.  I ended up with Chicken Adobo, the mung beans stew (mongo), a stewed pork (i think it was binagoongan) ... and taro leaves in coconut milk - all in small sizes - along in with a side of rice.  so so so yummy.  For ME, everything hit the spot and took me 'home' to my childhood.  I was pleasantly surprised at the flavours and quality.  Perhaps it was because I was hungry, perhaps because it was just that good.  Hard to tell.  

Neighbourhood is a bit sketchy - some might not feel 'comfortable' eating in the restaurant, though there is seating.  I took mine to go and ate in my room - and would likely have preferred to do that, simply because my room was more comfortable.

Anyway - worth a shot.  Definitely don't bother ordering online in advance. There will not be a long wait, as it's pretty much ready to serve - and you never know what will still be available at any given time.

Enjoy!

excerpts: fan-- haha, friends tried the TOCILOG (marinated pork with garlic friend rice and egg) and the PAKSIW NA TAPA (pork leg, knuckles) and the CHICKEN ADOBO (chicken cooked with soy sauce and vinegar).
chicken adobo.author: Shela D.
chicken adobo.review:
Ordered the LAING (Taro leaves with coconut milk) and the DINIGUAN (pork blood stew) and it was delicious! Boyfriend got the typical LONGSILOG (marinated pork sausage with garlic friend rice and egg), a true diehard and fan-- haha, friends tried the TOCILOG (marinated pork with garlic friend rice and egg) and the PAKSIW NA TAPA (pork leg, knuckles) and the CHICKEN ADOBO (chicken cooked with soy sauce and vinegar). 

We all left super satisfied and bellies full of delicious food! -- May I add, I've been eating Filipino food all my life, and after 28 years, I think I know what "authentic" Filipino food taste like.

The staff is super friendly and once I started speaking Tagalog, she started called me "iha" which means little daughter. 

Definitely a hidden gem inside of civic center. A lot of their food is pre-cooked so you can order and be on your way! Highly recommend if you're looking for authentic Filipino food!

excerpts: Favorites: laing, mongo beans, lechon kawali and chicken adobo.
chicken adobo.author: Javid S.
chicken adobo.review:
Authentic filipino food, hella big portions, everything made with lots of love. 

Favorites: laing, mongo beans, lechon kawali and chicken adobo.

excerpts: I had the chicken adobo which was a healthy portion enough for two meals; spot on in terms of saltiness, tender, and fattening haha.
Also had a pork and egg dish that I don't remember what it was called, but that too was good.
I generally recommend getting the medium or large size and saving the leftovers for future meals, as the small serving size seemed pretty small, so you're not getting as much for your dollar.
The sweetest auntie serving food here.
Would come again.
chicken adobo.author: Will H.
chicken adobo.review: Definitely a hole in the wall, so make sure you're okay with that (c'mon, quit being a snob!). I took some yelpers advice and ordered and dined in which resulted in what seemed like a bigger portion of food (compared to a friend of ordered to-go). I had the chicken adobo which was a healthy portion enough for two meals; spot on in terms of saltiness, tender, and fattening haha. Also had a pork and egg dish that I don't remember what it was called, but that too was good. I generally recommend getting the medium or large size and saving the leftovers for future meals, as the small serving size seemed pretty small, so you're not getting as much for your dollar. The sweetest auntie serving food here. Would come again.

excerpts: I got the chicken adobo with rice..
I pretty much got rice with adobo sauce.
They gave me a huge portion of rice with tiniest 4 pieces of chicken.
chicken adobo.author: Ayana K.
chicken adobo.review:
Had a hankering for Filipino food. I got the chicken adobo with rice.. I pretty much got rice with adobo sauce. They gave me a huge portion of rice with tiniest 4 pieces of chicken. If I put them all together it would not even make s whole thigh..

The flavor was good but the portion is definitely not worth the $7.50 I paid.. I could have gone to the Filipino place on 23rd & Mission Kababayan and got three times more food for the same price.. 

BE VERY CAREFUL AS WELL!! I FOUND HAIR IN MY FOOD!!! Ewwwwwww

Not a place I would go back to.. The people that worked there were also nice..

excerpts: Just as we were ready to walk away, a passerby on the street stopped us and said we would love it, and recommended that we get the chicken adobo with a bowl of rice and the pork lumpia.
The chicken adobo was delicious, the pork lumpia was also quite good.
The whole meal cost $14 (with 2 cans of pop!)
and was more than enough food for the two of us.
The atmosphere of the place is on par with your average take out joint, so don't expect much, but if you're looking for some inexpensive and delicious food, give this place a shot.
chicken adobo.author: Jesse W.
chicken adobo.review:
Delicious! This was my first time trying Filipino cuisine, and despite some initial hesitation, I was very pleasantly surprised. 

Looking for an inexpensive lunch, we found this place near our hotel on Yelp and decided to give it a try based on the reviews. However, staring at the menu outside, we had no idea what to order. Just as we were ready to walk away, a passerby on the street stopped us and said we would love it, and recommended that we get the chicken adobo with a bowl of rice and the pork lumpia. 

With guidance like that, we couldn't turn away and boy am I glad we didn't. The chicken adobo was delicious, the pork lumpia was also quite good. The whole meal cost $14 (with 2 cans of pop!) and was more than enough food for the two of us. The atmosphere of the place is on par with your average take out joint, so don't expect much, but if you're looking for some inexpensive and delicious food, give this place a shot.

excerpts: My wife got chicken adobo which was tasty as well.
chicken adobo.author: Max W.
chicken adobo.review: Really good food. I've been craving Filipino food for a while and was glad I came here. It is kalenderia style with some short order. I was really pleased with selection of foods. I got sinigang pork and was transported back to the Philippines. It wasn't too sour. I also ordered the Laing was happy with that. My wife got chicken adobo which was tasty as well. Got turon or fried banana. Was pleased with it especially since they added jackfruit in it. Would come back again.

excerpts: Also got my delivery order wrong gave me pork adobo instead of what I ordered chicken adobo.
Would eat here again with a few adjustments on what to order.
chicken adobo.author: Jay H.
chicken adobo.review: Most the food is good got the Longansilog and Tosilog egg was cooked well.  The Garlic fried rice like others have said tasted stale.  Way to hard and dry.  Should have just gotten steam rice instead with the silogs.  Also got my delivery order wrong gave me pork adobo instead of what I ordered chicken adobo.  Would eat here again with a few adjustments on what to order.

excerpts: I came in too late and they were out of chicken adobo.
chicken adobo.author: gabriel o.
chicken adobo.review:
Stayed at a hotel nearby for a conference. Ended up eating here three times. Twice for breakfast. 

The food is very authentic buffet style. For dinner I have had the menudo and the bistek. I came in too late and they were out of chicken adobo.

For breakfast I have had the tosino and the longanisa combos. They gave me a sample of the adobo squid and I wish I weren't heading home tonight or I would be back for that. It tasted delicious.

excerpts: I passed on that offer all the same and ordered small portions of the bistek, chicken adobo, and an eggplant omelette.
chicken adobo.author: Chris C.
chicken adobo.review:
This was my first trip to San Francisco and my first visit to a Filipino restaurant, and I very much enjoyed both.  I arrived about thirty minutes before closing to dine in and was not feeling in any way rushed.  Although I have enjoyed some success cooking a few Filipino dishes at home and have read up some on the cuisine, I still was unfamiliar with many of the courses being served.  The woman working the counter was very patient and explained to me what each of the dishes were and offered the opportunity to try the dishes before ordering - not many places that I have been to allow you to do that.  It was as if I was a guest at the family table.  I passed on that offer all the same and ordered small portions of the bistek, chicken adobo, and an eggplant omelette.  It was all quite flavorful and a nice dinner and experience on my last night in the Bay Area.

The venue is not fancy and the cuisine is not decorated with any sort of intricate garnish or served on expensive place settings.  If you're a tourist seeking that kind of experience, do your homework and go somewhere else.  For an experience that is more along the lines of filling your plate with good honest Filipino home cooking in a reasonable yet modest setting, I believe that this probably hits pretty close to the mark.  I plan to return on my next stay in SF.  Enjoy!

excerpts: I went for the chicken adobo and laing (taro root leaves, shrimp, pork, and coconut milk) and both really hit the spot.
Portions are large enough to feed two people or a light dinner for yourself latter.
chicken adobo.author: Sylvia D.
chicken adobo.review:
Geez, who knew finding a good place for lunch in San Francisco would be so difficult? I figured the city would be littered with good eats, but I'm beginning to think they're located everywhere except within walking distance of my workplace in Union Square. Sorry, but spending double-digits for lunch in a mall food court is unacceptable, even if people hail the San Francisco Shopping Centre as the best mall food court ever. (Note to self: Before accepting a job offer, consider salary, benefits, and local dining options. I'm kidding... Maybe.) 

Kusina Ni Tess, I should've known you would be the answer to my stomach's prayers! I walk by this tiny restaurant on my way to work and the delicious smell of homemade Filipino cuisine wafts through the cold morning air. I turn my head and do a double-take every time as if to check out a hot Filipino guy, but better - hot Filipino fooooood!

I finally had a chance to try Kusina Ni Tess. The food is served a la carte and for a mere $7, I got a white rice and my choice of two sides. The woman there was very nice and offered samples of Filipino dishes I haven't tried before. I went for the chicken adobo and laing (taro root leaves, shrimp, pork, and coconut milk) and both really hit the spot. Portions are large enough to feed two people or a light dinner for yourself latter. Gotta love that!

Four stars for this hole-in-the-wall jewel that won't put a dent in your wallet and feeds you a ton of food just like a typical Filipino mom!

(P.S. Kusina Ni Tess is sandwiched between an adult bookstore/videostore and a liquor store. A perfect storm? I'll let you decide!)

excerpts: For just a little over $5.00 I was able to order a plate of rice, chicken adobo and a side of soup.
chicken adobo.author: Yong Jae C.
chicken adobo.review:
I was in SF for a couple of days of training and decided to check out this restaurant since it was close to where I was. Plus I really enjoy Filipino food. 

It's a very small location. There are just a handful of places to sit and it's very narrow. I got the sense that most people ordered their food to go. I on the other hand ate there and because it was so small had to share a table with another customer.

While it's probably not the freshest Filipino food being sold I couldn't complain because their price was so cheap. They have their food on burners and sitting out kind of like if you were to go to Panda Express. For the price you can't complain. For just a little over $5.00 I was able to order a plate of rice, chicken adobo and a side of soup.

Servers were friendly. Not very talkative but they were also somewhat busy. I would definitely go back but I just wish they had more space.

excerpts:
we decided on:

kare-kare
chicken adobo
a sour-ish soup that i don't remember the name of

super.
chicken adobo.author: Shawn C.
chicken adobo.review:
alright! my first filipino food.

we didn't have a clue, and it showed. the lady at the counter was super helpful describing what they had that day. 

we decided on:

kare-kare
chicken adobo
a sour-ish soup that i don't remember the name of

super. delish.

it was $9 and some change for food + drink for one. my filipino colleagues tell me the price is a little high for the quality and surroundings, but hey. SF, right?

i don't live or work in the neighborhood so i don't see myself going back often, but still nice to check another cuisine off the list.

excerpts: The entrees on the steamer trays look so enticing:  chicken adobo, ginisang upo, lumpia, Dinuguan, etc.
We were all smiles as we put in our order:  Dinuguan (the famous chocolate meat you keep hearing about, ain't really chocolate!) , Paksiw na Bangus and rice.
For dessert, we each had the $1 Banana Que.

(banana rolled in brown sugar and fried)

Dinuguan is a stew usually cooked with pig's entrails simmered in pork's blood, garlic, chili and vinegar.
chicken adobo.author: Janice C.
chicken adobo.review:
I love these lunch dates with my aunt. 

She's been commuting to SF for as long as I can remember and works downtown.  Imagine my delight when she sent me an email and asked me if I wanted to have lunch with her.

She was so excited to show me this "hole in the wall" Filipino restaurant right across the Hilton (on Mason and Taylor st).  Leave it to my aunt to find a place that won't burn a hole in my pocket either.

Walking in, I felt like I was going into somebody's home.  I was warmly greeted with smiles from the staff behind the counter, even the cook deep-frying the Tilapia turned his head to smile.   The TV is tuned into the ubiquitous (amongst Filipinos anyway) TFC which stands for The Filipino Channel.   There are a couple of tables and stools for those who want to eat in. 

The entrees on the steamer trays look so enticing:  chicken adobo, ginisang upo, lumpia, Dinuguan, etc.  

We were all smiles as we put in our order:  Dinuguan (the famous chocolate meat you keep hearing about, ain't really chocolate!) , Paksiw na Bangus and rice.  For dessert, we each had the $1 Banana Que.  (banana rolled in brown sugar and fried)

Dinuguan is a stew usually cooked with pig's entrails simmered in pork's blood, garlic, chili and vinegar.  But here at Kusina ni Tess, it's made with pork's meat.  A little bit on the fatty side and it could be more spicier. 

The Paksiw na Bangus is made with milkfish, garlic, lots of ginger, bittermelon, and thin slices of eggplant.  I don't recall this dish being traditionally made with bittermelon or eggplant, but I guess, it's a good way to get your veggie for the day. 

The food here is definitely worth a try, and most of the entrees come with rice.  (the lady told us we can have extra rice if we need it) Our meal came to a total of $17 and the servings were enough for two people.  

You can't beat that price for decent Filipino food.

excerpts: I ordered the caldereta, chicken adobo, lumpia and tocino.
Everything was just perfect.
chicken adobo.author: Patrick T.
chicken adobo.review: I live in the Chicago suburbs and there's not a lot of Filipino restaurants. This place it's authentic Filipino food turo turo style. I ordered the caldereta, chicken adobo, lumpia and tocino. Everything was just perfect.

excerpts: We ended up getting rice with 4 items (dinuguan, chicken adobo, bbq chicken kebab, pork picadillo) and beef broth soup (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=_UQu0_EkMapVmWaKyhokIA).
The portions were generous and we took home plenty of leftovers.
All the dishes were incredibly flavourful!
My favourite was the well-marinated and very tender BBQ CHICKEN (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=K6hvMnOPgLoOxCHeDRkSYQ).
Another great dish was the CHICKEN ADOBO (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=V5i46q0uLZkzPKkl8sI13g), which was vinegary with lots of tender chicken.
The DINUGUAN, a pork blood stew (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=qyvbG-mXwjzfVgtzbWGPhQ), had a ton of pork - in fact, it was ALL pork.
I actually would've liked to see some snout, ears, and intestines.
Flavour-wise
it was tasty and vinegary but not the best I've had.
chicken adobo.author: Steph L.
chicken adobo.review:
Let's face it, Filipino food is not for the diet and/or health conscious. After eating it I'm usually left craving salad - and I don't even like salad! That being said, I will excuse the predominance of salt and oil in many of the dishes because the food is so tasty. High cholesterol and hypertension? Bring it on!
 
I took my mom here for lunch while she was visiting. After a weekend of dining at restaurants such as Wayfare Tavern, Bobo's, Izakaya Sozai, Canteen, and Laurel Court (in the Fairmont hotel), I gotta say that this was one of the better (and definitely cheapest!) meals we had.
 
The food itself is worthy of 4 stars, but what brings this unassuming hole-in-the-wall to 5-star status is the incredible service. They were all SOOO nice! Though I'm familiar with a few Filipino dishes by no means am I an expert. In fact, most of their stews and other offerings were foreign to me. Not only was the lady behind the counter extremely patient in describing all the dishes to me, she let me sample most of them! I must've tried at least 5 things before ordering.

We ended up getting rice with 4 items (dinuguan, chicken adobo, bbq chicken kebab, pork picadillo) and beef broth soup (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=_UQu0_EkMapVmWaKyhokIA). The portions were generous and we took home plenty of leftovers. All the dishes were incredibly flavourful! My favourite was the well-marinated and very tender BBQ CHICKEN (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=K6hvMnOPgLoOxCHeDRkSYQ). Another great dish was the CHICKEN ADOBO (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=V5i46q0uLZkzPKkl8sI13g), which was vinegary with lots of tender chicken. The DINUGUAN, a pork blood stew (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=qyvbG-mXwjzfVgtzbWGPhQ), had a ton of pork - in fact, it was ALL pork. I actually would've liked to see some snout, ears, and intestines. Flavour-wise it was tasty and vinegary but not the best I've had. The PICADILLO (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=IpXhx2tf21QPFRQbmVOPGw) was an aromatic stew with ground pork, potatoes, onions, peas, and carrots. 

As you can see, all we ordered was meat. (Vegetables don't exactly come to mind when I think of Filipino food...) While we were eating, the chef prepared a fresh batch of vegetables and offered us some on the house! Free food? SCORE! We got about half a serving of tasty eggplant, pumpkin, green beans, and bitter melon sautéed with shrimp paste (I think, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=ZgebMZj4ih7ppohwK9mp6Q). Like everything else, this was so flavourful, but definitely not as heavy.

At the end of our meal I realized I forgot to get some LUMPIAS. Being as stuffed as we already were, I didn't want to get a whole order (of 6) so I got a half order for $1.50 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=3UJ0ZkOLaachSKOqamv5xA). These were made to order so they're guaranteed to be hot and crispy.

They must have seen my mom and me eyeing the BIBINGKA sitting on the counter, because they offered us a free sample of that as well! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=USTl04_CDuaRz2rgGG0cRQ) It's a rice flour cake with sliced salted eggs wrapped in banana leaf, which imparted a nice aroma to the cake.

I will definitely be back the next time I'm craving Filipino food, especially since I don't have to go all the way to Daly City! Their menu rotates on a daily basis and some things are only available on certain days, so check before you go! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=uRD3L1Hj55rM31R9egyioA)

excerpts:
We decided to do this family-style, and shared:
Pork Adobo: I've only ever had chicken adobo before, and this was a lot less vinegary and more gravy-y than what I remember.
The meat was really tender and flavourful, and there wasn't too much fat attached.
It was, however, kind of oily
but it wasn't too bad.
chicken adobo.author: Katie M.
chicken adobo.review:
My manager took me out to lunch for my birthday, and the place we originally wanted to go to had already closed their lunch service (it was 2PM), so we walked around and decided to come in here. 

First of all, let me say that this place isn't very clean and only has 4-5 small tables to sit at, but I'm assuming people get their food to go anyway. It reminds me of small family-run restaurants in Hong Kong, where most customers are regulars and don't mind how run-down it is. They had a television on a Filipino channel, so we got to enjoy some kind of Asian telenovela while we ate. The staff was friendly and did their own thing while we poked and peeked around. 

I think we had just missed the lunch rush here, so they didn't have any noodles left. White rice it is! Carbs on carbs. We decided to do this family-style, and shared:
Pork Adobo: I've only ever had chicken adobo before, and this was a lot less vinegary and more gravy-y than what I remember. The meat was really tender and flavourful, and there wasn't too much fat attached. It was, however, kind of oily but it wasn't too bad.
Laing: Probably my favourite part of my meal. This is taro leaves cooked in coconut milk. It tastes like sweet curry, and it melts in your mouth. Because it's veggies, it feels healthy and it's amazing with rice. CARBS ON CARBS.
BBQ Pork Skewers: Well, I really like barbeque and skewers, so no complaints here. I would've preferred chicken or beef, because I've never really understood what pork tastes like... 
Tinapa: The meat on their fried fish was a little on the dry side, and was hard to eat without really getting our hands dirty (damn flimsy plastic forks), but I really liked how they seasoned/marinated it. Not too salty and the skin was very crispy.
Beef Stew: This was really bland, and I had maybe 30% of mine. I think they were trying to get rid of it, because there were no veggies and no beef, just broth and oil. Nope.

We each got a huge plate of rice, and the portions were huge for one person. Everything came to $23, which is really cheap for how much food we got! I think this was my first time having an authentic Filipino meal, and I will definitely come by again to try more items.

excerpts: The chicken adobo was flavorful without being overly salty or vinegary, and now that I've discovered that you can request it to be fried, I'll have to try that common variation as well!
chicken adobo.author: Jake m.
chicken adobo.review:
The best Filipino food I've ever had to pay for! The selection, which rotates from day to day, is quite diverse and can accommodate a vegetarian satisfactorily, of which I am not. Otherwise, and this is true generally of Filipino cuisine, the meat dishes are the focal points. For sheer variety this place would make me think twice about going home for a Filipino meal. The chicken adobo was flavorful without being overly salty or vinegary, and now that I've discovered that you can request it to be fried, I'll have to try that common variation as well! The laing we ordered didn't contain any shrimp or meat, just the taro leaves and coconut milk, and was delicious just the same, a very comforting food. The dinuguan was, hands down, my favorite part of my meal, and it surprised my companions with its quality, especially after they'd gotten a sample and brief explanation of what it is (pork butt in pork blood). Our meals came with rice and some "soup" which was actually just sinigang broth without the bok choy and beef. 

The location is pretty small and its exterior hardly stands out (despite the bright yellow awning), a real hole-in-the-wall place, but none of this should matter given the delicious and authentic food. And the gentleman (who reigns from Bulacan!) who is frequently at the door is genuinely invested in providing a filling meal. My companions are relatively new to Filipino food and loved all of it. In fact, we bartered over who was going to be taking what after we'd stuffed our faces. 

I've been searching for quality Filipino spots in the city since moving here, and though this is actually my first stop, it'll probably be the primary one. I've yet to try the rellenong bangus or kare-kare, but will be trying them out soon.

excerpts: Unfortunately, the  over oily chicken adobo, bland noodles, and lumpias that I ate were not very good.
chicken adobo.author: Ed W.
chicken adobo.review:
Kusina Ni Tess is a hole-in-the-wall eatery serving home cooking Filipino food.  Home cooking usually means the food is yummy, just like how your mom cooks it. Unfortunately, the  over oily chicken adobo, bland noodles, and lumpias that I ate were not very good. They tasted exactly like the dishes my mom made--not tasty. 

Worse, the portions were very small and the prices were quite high. I am not a big eater. But I were still hungry after I ate two small pieces of chicken (~$3.5), noodles (~$3.5), and six lumpias ($3) and had to eat a burger at Carl's Jr. 

Skip it!

excerpts: The Chicken adobo - greasy (actually, they should rename this dish to chicken swimming in grease and a little bit of soy sauce).
The pork Chop - greasy.
The Sinigang -super greasy (little chunks of fat swimming around in your soup).
Agh!
chicken adobo.author: Clarice V.
chicken adobo.review:
I am so sorry.  I am really sorry.  I don't want to do my Filipino peeps any harm.  I will eat in the dingy-est dive in town (even to Pakwan with their basmati-cockrochi rice) but man, it's just not cool when the restaurant fries fish two inches away from you. 

I was at Kusina ni Tess with some non-Filipino co-workers (it was their idea, not mine) this afternoon and Tess decides to fry up a boat load of milkfish (bangus). My co-workers didn't complain (I guess they didn't want to offend) but we seriously left the place smelling like Pacific Super.   

The food was below average - everything was greasy, greasy, greasy(the forks and spoons were still a little greasy from the last patron).  The Chicken adobo - greasy (actually, they should rename this dish to chicken swimming in grease and a little bit of soy sauce). The pork Chop - greasy. The Sinigang -super greasy (little chunks of fat swimming around in your soup). Agh! Why can't Filipinos here cook without so much grease? 

Judging by the lunchtime crowd, it is obvious that the Hilton Hotel workers keep this restaurant alive.  If I were Filipino and worked at the Hilton, I would demand for a little bit more quality from Tess.
I know that most of them don't really have a choice (there really is no other Filipino place around) - but please Hilton workers, next time you are at Tess', tell her to cut the grease a little.

excerpts: I ordered Lechon kawali
and it's not even crispy
like it's supposed to be, not to mention the "no sauce" to go with it.
I've had better Filipino food that's reasonably priced.
lechon kawali.author: Ava M.
lechon kawali.review: We ordered delivery through DoorDash and I have to say it's very disappointing. First of all the food is overpriced, for the portion that they give, it's way overpriced. I ordered Lechon kawali and it's not even crispy like it's supposed to be, not to mention the "no sauce" to go with it. I've had better Filipino food that's reasonably priced.

excerpts: For as little as $25 for two people, we were able to share pork BBQ, Kare-Kare (peanut butter based oxtail stew), Sinigang na Baboy (tamarind pork soup) and Lechon Kawali (crispy pork belly) with a serving of white rice.
lechon kawali.author: Reggie M.
lechon kawali.review:
This hole-in-the-wall Filipino food eatery at Tenderloin in San Francisco delivers authentic Filipino comfort food. The ambiance is very casual and reminded me of most local eateries in Manila where you just simply point out the dishes you want to the server behind the counter. The cooking style is very familiar, as if it was something that your mom, aunt or grandma cooked for you.

For as little as $25 for two people, we were able to share pork BBQ, Kare-Kare (peanut butter based oxtail stew), Sinigang na Baboy (tamarind pork soup) and Lechon Kawali (crispy pork belly) with a serving of white rice.

The staff are genuinely friendly and helpful. This place is ideal for a quick lunch. It is also a great training ground for your non Filipino spouse, especially if you intend to take them with you on your next visit to the Philippines.

excerpts:
Ordered cornsilog and lechon kawali. 

Just the prices are a little pricy end up paying 19.85 for cornsilog, lechon kawali and calamansi juice.

Just the prices are a little pricy end up paying 19.85 for cornsilog, lechon kawali and calamansi juice.

$9.00 for cornsilog
$6.50?

lechon kawali.review:
Went and had my lunch here before flying back to las vegas. 

Ordered cornsilog and lechon kawali. 

Typical filipino food nothing too special. Just the prices are a little pricy end up paying 19.85 for cornsilog, lechon kawali and calamansi juice.

excerpts: I ordered one main entrée of pork menudo (with white rice), a side of pork lumpia, and a side of lechon kawali.
lechon kawali.author: Joe N.
lechon kawali.review:
I found this place on accident trying to find dinner.  The restaurant itself has no bells and whistles, just some tables to eat on and a TV playing Filipino shows.  The staff was very friendly explaining what they had to offer as well as what was planned for the next day's menu.  The food was on par with what I would expect from Filipino food...just like I would have eaten at home or at a party.  The prices were affordable as well.  I ordered one main entrée of pork menudo (with white rice), a side of pork lumpia, and a side of lechon kawali.  More than enough food for one person and could have made two meals out of it if I weren't so hungry.

The only downside is that even though certain dishes are listed on the menu, it is not offered.  Not a deal breaker though.  The dishes are served cafeteria style, so what ever is there is what they have available.  

I would definitely return for the food!

excerpts: Favorites: laing, mongo beans, lechon kawali and chicken adobo.
lechon kawali.author: Javid S.
lechon kawali.review:
Authentic filipino food, hella big portions, everything made with lots of love. 

Favorites: laing, mongo beans, lechon kawali and chicken adobo.

excerpts: Lechon kawali (with rice).
They offered Mang Tomas to go with it, and which I regret not getting.
I got very fatty pieces with very little meat.
But they served it hot-hot which I liked.
Wasn't totally impressed
lechon kawali.author: Sheryl D.
lechon kawali.review:
Kusina Ni Tess is across the street from the Hilton and the next block over from Parc55. Despite a couple days of going back and forth repeatedly between the two hotels (to attend a conference) I didn't even see the restaurant. It's this tiny hole-in-the-wall that I only noticed while looking out the window at the Hilton during a break between sessions. But, my god, did I love this place so much that I had lunch here 3 times over a 4-day period. This joint is what I desperately needed after traveling and eating meals of anything but Filipino food.

First meal: Lechon kawali (with rice). They offered Mang Tomas to go with it, and which I regret not getting. I got very fatty pieces with very little meat. But they served it hot-hot which I liked. Wasn't totally impressed but I decided to return and give them another try.

Second meal: Deep fried tilapia (with rice). Now, if you don't know how to eat fish with bones, don't get this because you get the whole she-bang (eyes, tail, and all!). Setting that technicality aside, it was, again, served hot-hot and it hit the spot (especially with the soy sauce).

Third meal: Adobo and mechado (with rice). Solid adobo. Mechado not so good, but decent.

The two ladies that work the register and counter were super patient. I will be back!!!

excerpts: Wish we got there in time for some lechon kawali.
Our fault :(
lechon kawali.author: Teresa M.
lechon kawali.review: Legit food. It was a nice break from BK, McD and diner fare.  The lumpia was great. Wish we got there in time for some lechon kawali.  Our fault :(

excerpts: Dinuguan, Menudo, Lumpia and for dessert
Bibingka was all we could fit in for lunch, or we would have ordered more The owners  treated everyone like family as they entered the door.
Typical Filipino hospitality
dinuguan.author: Lorelli R.
dinuguan.review: Nestled in the heart of downtown San Francisco is a simple yet delicious place for Authentic Filipino food. Dinuguan, Menudo, Lumpia and for dessert Bibingka was all we could fit in for lunch, or we would have ordered more The owners  treated everyone like family as they entered the door. Typical Filipino hospitality

excerpts: and I had dinuguan which is one of my favorite Filipino dishes.
They reheated the dish in microwave; not how I would prefer for a blood dish as the oil and blood separates because of too much heat.
They didn't have a combo option
so I had to order and pay for each item individually as opposed to getting some discount for a combo.
The dinuguan didn't taste great either.
dinuguan.author: Frances D.
dinuguan.review:
It was my first time here and I had dinuguan which is one of my favorite Filipino dishes. They reheated the dish in microwave; not how I would prefer for a blood dish as the oil and blood separates because of too much heat. They didn't have a combo option so I had to order and pay for each item individually as opposed to getting some discount for a combo. The dinuguan didn't taste great either.

I also had Turon for dessert but it was served cold. They don't have something to keep things warm. I was expecting it would something special in it like Langka or something. But it was just plain banana and not even very ripe one. Not something I would pay for $1.50

And worst of all, I vomitted that night. I knew it was their dish because I didn't eat anything else new other that.

It was not a good experience and I will not go here again.

excerpts: I got small pork adobo, small dinuguan, small lechon.
Total was $21.
A bit pricey frankly, but the food itself is very good.
The adobo and dinuguan is tender and flavorful.
The Lechon is deep fried a second time to warm it up, making it very crispy and flavorful.
I took it all home
and I really wish I stayed at the restaurant to eat it
The second time I came back, I got a medium size of pork adobo and small lechon plus a scoop of rice.
I definitely could have gotten a small adobo instead because the medium was HUGE.
dinuguan.author: edward k.
dinuguan.review:
EAT-IN DO NOT TAKE OUT IF YOU CAN HELP IT!!!!! The reason I say this is because the portions are easily 1.5x-2x if you eat in house.

Now on to the food. The first the I came. I got small pork adobo, small dinuguan, small lechon. Total was $21. A bit pricey frankly, but the food itself is very good. The adobo and dinuguan is tender and flavorful. The Lechon is deep fried a second time to warm it up, making it very crispy and flavorful. I took it all home and I really wish I stayed at the restaurant to eat it because like I said... portions.

The second time I came back, I got a medium size of pork adobo and small lechon plus a scoop of rice. $18. I definitely could have gotten a small adobo instead because the medium was HUGE.  The ladies are very generous with the portions when you eat in and its totally worth it.

Overall, the food is very good. Prices could be a bit cheaper. I've been to much cheaper filipino joints but this is the best the city has in this area.

excerpts: My favorites are the dinuguan and the Laing.
dinuguan.author: Rae C.
dinuguan.review:
A bit expensive, but the food is really good. My favorites are the dinuguan and the Laing. Can't go wrong with those two. 

Plus, the ladies serving are very helpful and friendly. :)

excerpts: The entrees on the steamer trays look so enticing:  chicken adobo, ginisang upo, lumpia, Dinuguan, etc.
We were all smiles as we put in our order:  Dinuguan (the famous chocolate meat you keep hearing about, ain't really chocolate!) , Paksiw na Bangus and rice.
For dessert, we each had the $1 Banana Que.

(banana rolled in brown sugar and fried)

Dinuguan is a stew usually cooked with pig's entrails simmered in pork's blood, garlic, chili and vinegar.
dinuguan.author: Janice C.
dinuguan.review:
I love these lunch dates with my aunt. 

She's been commuting to SF for as long as I can remember and works downtown.  Imagine my delight when she sent me an email and asked me if I wanted to have lunch with her.

She was so excited to show me this "hole in the wall" Filipino restaurant right across the Hilton (on Mason and Taylor st).  Leave it to my aunt to find a place that won't burn a hole in my pocket either.

Walking in, I felt like I was going into somebody's home.  I was warmly greeted with smiles from the staff behind the counter, even the cook deep-frying the Tilapia turned his head to smile.   The TV is tuned into the ubiquitous (amongst Filipinos anyway) TFC which stands for The Filipino Channel.   There are a couple of tables and stools for those who want to eat in. 

The entrees on the steamer trays look so enticing:  chicken adobo, ginisang upo, lumpia, Dinuguan, etc.  

We were all smiles as we put in our order:  Dinuguan (the famous chocolate meat you keep hearing about, ain't really chocolate!) , Paksiw na Bangus and rice.  For dessert, we each had the $1 Banana Que.  (banana rolled in brown sugar and fried)

Dinuguan is a stew usually cooked with pig's entrails simmered in pork's blood, garlic, chili and vinegar.  But here at Kusina ni Tess, it's made with pork's meat.  A little bit on the fatty side and it could be more spicier. 

The Paksiw na Bangus is made with milkfish, garlic, lots of ginger, bittermelon, and thin slices of eggplant.  I don't recall this dish being traditionally made with bittermelon or eggplant, but I guess, it's a good way to get your veggie for the day. 

The food here is definitely worth a try, and most of the entrees come with rice.  (the lady told us we can have extra rice if we need it) Our meal came to a total of $17 and the servings were enough for two people.  

You can't beat that price for decent Filipino food.

excerpts: We ordered the dinuguan and kaldereta with a side of broth and rice (of course!).
We just couldn't get enough!
I ended up getting food and snacks to go to curb my craving for the next week.
I can't wait to come back!
dinuguan.author: Gaile G.
dinuguan.review: When you're craving home cookin', and I mean REALLY crave it, you would go to the ends of the Earth to get what you need. But I was definitely happier to find that I could just go the city to get it. Filipino food is non-existent in Sonoma County, so if you're in the mood the easiest (and best) trek is to get here at Kusina Ni Tess. It's a hole-in-the-wall, mom and pop joint and you feel right at home as you walk in. Tito (as I want to call him) will just ask what you want and have you take a seat to immediately enjoy the heavenly food. We ordered the dinuguan and kaldereta with a side of broth and rice (of course!). We just couldn't get enough! I ended up getting food and snacks to go to curb my craving for the next week. I can't wait to come back!

excerpts: We ended up getting rice with 4 items (dinuguan, chicken adobo, bbq chicken kebab, pork picadillo) and beef broth soup (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=_UQu0_EkMapVmWaKyhokIA).
The portions were generous and we took home plenty of leftovers.
All the dishes were incredibly flavourful!
My favourite was the well-marinated and very tender BBQ CHICKEN (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=K6hvMnOPgLoOxCHeDRkSYQ).
Another great dish was the CHICKEN ADOBO (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=V5i46q0uLZkzPKkl8sI13g), which was vinegary with lots of tender chicken.
The DINUGUAN, a pork blood stew (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=qyvbG-mXwjzfVgtzbWGPhQ), had a ton of pork - in fact, it was ALL pork.
I actually would've liked to see some snout, ears, and intestines.
Flavour-wise
it was tasty and vinegary but not the best I've had.
dinuguan.author: Steph L.
dinuguan.review:
Let's face it, Filipino food is not for the diet and/or health conscious. After eating it I'm usually left craving salad - and I don't even like salad! That being said, I will excuse the predominance of salt and oil in many of the dishes because the food is so tasty. High cholesterol and hypertension? Bring it on!
 
I took my mom here for lunch while she was visiting. After a weekend of dining at restaurants such as Wayfare Tavern, Bobo's, Izakaya Sozai, Canteen, and Laurel Court (in the Fairmont hotel), I gotta say that this was one of the better (and definitely cheapest!) meals we had.
 
The food itself is worthy of 4 stars, but what brings this unassuming hole-in-the-wall to 5-star status is the incredible service. They were all SOOO nice! Though I'm familiar with a few Filipino dishes by no means am I an expert. In fact, most of their stews and other offerings were foreign to me. Not only was the lady behind the counter extremely patient in describing all the dishes to me, she let me sample most of them! I must've tried at least 5 things before ordering.

We ended up getting rice with 4 items (dinuguan, chicken adobo, bbq chicken kebab, pork picadillo) and beef broth soup (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=_UQu0_EkMapVmWaKyhokIA). The portions were generous and we took home plenty of leftovers. All the dishes were incredibly flavourful! My favourite was the well-marinated and very tender BBQ CHICKEN (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=K6hvMnOPgLoOxCHeDRkSYQ). Another great dish was the CHICKEN ADOBO (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=V5i46q0uLZkzPKkl8sI13g), which was vinegary with lots of tender chicken. The DINUGUAN, a pork blood stew (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=qyvbG-mXwjzfVgtzbWGPhQ), had a ton of pork - in fact, it was ALL pork. I actually would've liked to see some snout, ears, and intestines. Flavour-wise it was tasty and vinegary but not the best I've had. The PICADILLO (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=IpXhx2tf21QPFRQbmVOPGw) was an aromatic stew with ground pork, potatoes, onions, peas, and carrots. 

As you can see, all we ordered was meat. (Vegetables don't exactly come to mind when I think of Filipino food...) While we were eating, the chef prepared a fresh batch of vegetables and offered us some on the house! Free food? SCORE! We got about half a serving of tasty eggplant, pumpkin, green beans, and bitter melon sautéed with shrimp paste (I think, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=ZgebMZj4ih7ppohwK9mp6Q). Like everything else, this was so flavourful, but definitely not as heavy.

At the end of our meal I realized I forgot to get some LUMPIAS. Being as stuffed as we already were, I didn't want to get a whole order (of 6) so I got a half order for $1.50 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=3UJ0ZkOLaachSKOqamv5xA). These were made to order so they're guaranteed to be hot and crispy.

They must have seen my mom and me eyeing the BIBINGKA sitting on the counter, because they offered us a free sample of that as well! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=USTl04_CDuaRz2rgGG0cRQ) It's a rice flour cake with sliced salted eggs wrapped in banana leaf, which imparted a nice aroma to the cake.

I will definitely be back the next time I'm craving Filipino food, especially since I don't have to go all the way to Daly City! Their menu rotates on a daily basis and some things are only available on certain days, so check before you go! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=uRD3L1Hj55rM31R9egyioA)

excerpts: The dinuguan was, hands down, my favorite part of my meal, and it surprised my companions with its quality, especially after they'd gotten a sample and brief explanation of what it is (pork butt in pork blood).
dinuguan.author: Jake m.
dinuguan.review:
The best Filipino food I've ever had to pay for! The selection, which rotates from day to day, is quite diverse and can accommodate a vegetarian satisfactorily, of which I am not. Otherwise, and this is true generally of Filipino cuisine, the meat dishes are the focal points. For sheer variety this place would make me think twice about going home for a Filipino meal. The chicken adobo was flavorful without being overly salty or vinegary, and now that I've discovered that you can request it to be fried, I'll have to try that common variation as well! The laing we ordered didn't contain any shrimp or meat, just the taro leaves and coconut milk, and was delicious just the same, a very comforting food. The dinuguan was, hands down, my favorite part of my meal, and it surprised my companions with its quality, especially after they'd gotten a sample and brief explanation of what it is (pork butt in pork blood). Our meals came with rice and some "soup" which was actually just sinigang broth without the bok choy and beef. 

The location is pretty small and its exterior hardly stands out (despite the bright yellow awning), a real hole-in-the-wall place, but none of this should matter given the delicious and authentic food. And the gentleman (who reigns from Bulacan!) who is frequently at the door is genuinely invested in providing a filling meal. My companions are relatively new to Filipino food and loved all of it. In fact, we bartered over who was going to be taking what after we'd stuffed our faces. 

I've been searching for quality Filipino spots in the city since moving here, and though this is actually my first stop, it'll probably be the primary one. I've yet to try the rellenong bangus or kare-kare, but will be trying them out soon.

excerpts: I grabbed some pork afritada, pancit and dinuguan.
All three were pretty yummy... and the portions were huge.
dinuguan.author: Mark B.
dinuguan.review:
Yum.

My first hint that this would probably be good was the 10-deep line to get in at lunch time.

My second was that everybody eating at Tess' was Filipino.

Yes, it's a small place.  Yes, it's steam table food.  Yes, it can be crowded.  You consider these to be negative?!

I waited about 10 minutes to order my food.  While I was waiting, I watched them prep fresh dishes and move them to the steam table.  That's a Good Sign(tm).

I grabbed some pork afritada, pancit and dinuguan.  All three were pretty yummy... and the portions were huge.  I washed my meal down with two sodas and still spent less than $12... including the complimentary white rice.

If you're looking for individual seating here -- give up.  There are three tables set for four-tops.

You will, however, stand a good chance of grabbing a seat at the communal table in the back.  And you should.  Best seating in the house.

At the back table, seated with around eight people I'd never met before, I had a really nice lunch and a lot of warm, friendly and fun conversation.

The food here is very good... but the folks that work here and eat here make the place.

Going back to try the bangus :)

excerpts: Had a huge serving of rice with dinuguan (if you don't know what that is...better google it) and some chicken.
That with a can of coconut juice...all for $8.50.
Chicken was good, but the diniguan was a little runny and bland for my taste.
dinuguan.author: Mark D.
dinuguan.review: Swung by around 11am on a Saturday hoping that there would be some brunch-silog, but it was all lunch.  Considering that I didn't have to jump in my car and shoot down to Daly City/San Bruno, it wasn't too bad.  Definitely one of the better Filipino places in the city.  Had a huge serving of rice with dinuguan (if you don't know what that is...better google it) and some chicken.  That with a can of coconut juice...all for $8.50.  Chicken was good, but the diniguan was a little runny and bland for my taste.

excerpts: Manoksilog, pork sinigang, ?
sauteed taro leaves with coconut milk, and sisig.
All were good but we both loved the sinigang and taro leaves.
Would recommend.
pork sinigang.author: Daniel H.
pork sinigang.review: Very friendly staff. Food was very good. Girlfriend is Filipina and was impressed as well. We tried an array of foods: Manoksilog, pork sinigang, ?sauteed taro leaves with coconut milk, and sisig. All were good but we both loved the sinigang and taro leaves. Would recommend.

excerpts: Their pork sinigang is so good!
Not greasy, well-flavored and has balanced portions of meat and veggies.
They now accept credit cards too
but I usually pay with cash.
pork sinigang.author: HM N.
