pork sinigang.review: Seems like Kusina ni Tess has gotten better over the years since I first tried them. They've gone through a couple of updates/renovations (as far as I've noticed). Their space is bigger now, still a small place, but they have more tables and chairs where people can sit. Their food selection also seems to have expanded. I probably go there once every few months and they always have a good variety: laing, adobo, sinigang, corned beef, fried fish, turon, bibingka, kare kare and some others are usually on rotation. Their pork sinigang is so good! Not greasy, well-flavored and has balanced portions of meat and veggies. They now accept credit cards too but I usually pay with cash.

excerpts: I ordered one main entrée of pork menudo (with white rice), a side of pork lumpia, and a side of lechon kawali.
pork menudo.author: Joe N.
pork menudo.review:
I found this place on accident trying to find dinner.  The restaurant itself has no bells and whistles, just some tables to eat on and a TV playing Filipino shows.  The staff was very friendly explaining what they had to offer as well as what was planned for the next day's menu.  The food was on par with what I would expect from Filipino food...just like I would have eaten at home or at a party.  The prices were affordable as well.  I ordered one main entrée of pork menudo (with white rice), a side of pork lumpia, and a side of lechon kawali.  More than enough food for one person and could have made two meals out of it if I weren't so hungry.

The only downside is that even though certain dishes are listed on the menu, it is not offered.  Not a deal breaker though.  The dishes are served cafeteria style, so what ever is there is what they have available.  

I would definitely return for the food!

excerpts: I had my heart set on pork sisig which I love ...
and I probably wouldn't get again and would replace with Pork Sisig!
pork sisig.author: Rod M.
pork sisig.review:
Everybody go: Hotel, motel, holiday inn
You see, If you're walking down Ellis street better take a friend
Your boy likes Filipino food what can I say
Pancit n lumpia even Kare-Kare
Workin at KNT is Lola and Lolo no need to pout
Kusina Ni Tess is making food with love to stock the house
..........................................................................................................
If you like my reviews...give me a follow.

Super cool spot in the Ellis as other's have mentioned best to keep your eyes peeled in this neighborhood but that's any big city location right? 

Buffet, Chinese Fast food buffet-style set-up. They have a huge menu that lists all of their items for sale but be WARNED not everything is available that day.  I had my heart set on pork sisig which I love ...but it's only available on Tuesday and Friday's (sad face). 

So I went with (from fave to least fave)
Chicken Adobo - Always a safe choice and a Filipino staple. This was delish
Pork Sinigang- Also very tasty and flavorful
Beef Stew- Was the least fave and was a little too salty for my liking and I probably wouldn't get again and would replace with Pork Sisig! 

Super friendly service. They have a small , medium and large to-go options which range in price from like $7-$15 I wanna say. 

The venue itself is not that big so the start of the line is near the entrance/exit of the restaurant so it makes things kind of cramped near that area. 

Suggestion to the owners would be to list what foods are available and not available THAT DAY so people don't get their hopes up. A small touch but it leaves a positive taste in people's eyes.

All in all, a solid venue for Filipino home style cooking.

excerpts: One of my favorite dishes is laing & bopis.
Theres is plenty of food and dessert to choose from here.
My friends said their Kare Kare was hella good too.
laing.author: Ryan M.
laing.review:
The Owner:
Manny salamat for continuing the establishment of Tess to Kusina Ni Tess. Manny such a humbled individual with awesome workers. Great conversation in tagalog although you can hear my english accent I can still have a whole conversation.

The Food:
Thank God theres filipino food in the area of downtown/tl. I have been going here for the last 2-3  years. I just learned they have a different food menu day to day. Also by going on their renewed website KusinaNiTess.com you can see what they will be serving. You have the two main breakfast dishes silogs tocilog/longsilo. Today I had the bistek na bangus (boneless) mmmm sarap & longsilog. One of my favorite dishes is laing & bopis. Theres is plenty of food and dessert to choose from here. My friends said their Kare Kare was hella good too. I am looking forward to get some Kare Kare from here.

Filipinos:
A1 Treatment & knowledgeable to help you understand what food they cooked. You wont know how it tastes til you try it. Filipino's from all over come here as well as Filipino Artists, Actors & Actresses, from the Philippines & so forth. Holla at a filipino friend so they can tell you whats really good or you can ask me. Follow hashtag or #A1LifestyleSarap
#sarapcity (Forever)

excerpts: Ive been here a few times, including yesterday where I had the LAING (pronounced lying) which tara leaves and coconut milk , Sinegang , Binaguongan and beefsteak , which were all delicious !
My tummy said thank you and give me more.
They have a nice wide selection of food and a couple of desserts..
The service is great, your basic fun friendly Filipino staff ..
They were happy to take our money
and I was happy to eat their yummy cuisine !
In the words of The Terminator..
I'll be back"
laing.author: David S.
laing.review:
Ive been here a few times, including yesterday where I had the LAING (pronounced lying) which tara leaves and coconut milk , Sinegang , Binaguongan and beefsteak , which were all delicious ! 
My tummy said thank you and give me more. They have a nice wide selection of food and a couple of desserts.. 
The service is great, your basic fun friendly Filipino staff .. 
They were happy to take our money and I was happy to eat their yummy cuisine ! 
In the words of The Terminator.. "I'll be back"

excerpts: We got the LAING (taro leaves and spinach in coconut milk) and PORK STEW with vermicelli and melon.
Both were good, with a contrast between the creamy indulgent laing and the simple homemade stew.
Also, you feel less guilty than my usual guilt-tripping Filipino feast of abodo and lumpia, seeing that laing consists of good honest vegetables--swimming in coconut milk, but veggies nonetheless.
laing.author: Edna C.
laing.review:
How many people does it take to remember the name Kusina Ni Tess? Apparently more than two -_- After failed attempts at searching Ni and Kess, we gave up and searched Filipino in order to navigate to this epitome-of-hole-in-the-walls.

The hole-in-the-wall-ness has pluses and minuses. The ambiance is simple, modest, and cafeteria-like (yes, think prepared food in metal trays over steamers. And plastic trays.), and it's more of a lunch place because they close at 8pm and run out of stuff at the end of the day: only the food on display + desserts are available. (I guess another minus is the difficult name to remember)

The trade-off is the authenticity. Well.... to be fair my knowledge of Filipino food doesn't extend far beyond the various Filipino items at my school cafeteria and fusion brunch places that include longaniza sausage. However, I trust from my extensive foodie (wannabe) adventures that I have reasonable judgment of legit good food.
 
The lady serving us was friendly and I really appreciate all her patience with our n00biness and indecisiveness. It was nice of her to offer us samples of all the entrees (reminded me of ice cream... why can't all restaurants do this).  We got the LAING (taro leaves and spinach in coconut milk) and PORK STEW with vermicelli and melon. Both were good, with a contrast between the creamy indulgent laing and the simple homemade stew. Also, you feel less guilty than my usual guilt-tripping Filipino feast of abodo and lumpia, seeing that laing consists of good honest vegetables--swimming in coconut milk, but veggies nonetheless. We got a sausage as well: pretty tasty but not mind-blowing (not super enthusiastic how they dipped it in oil before serving)

We also sampled the PANCIT and GROUND PORK--not bad but rather salty so it's one of those things that you taste good in a sample but may be too much if you got an entire entree of it.

The HALO HALO is a must-get. We've never had it before but it was a delicious mix of flavors and textures, including soft pudding-like flan, chunky ube, starchy beans, crunchy shaved ice, and chewy jelly--makes pearl milk tea seem a little too basic... Frappucinos like something from the Stone Ages. I liked how it wasn't too sweet so made a satisfying and refreshing dessert.

Total was ~$20 for 2 people, and that rivals food trucks where you most likely have to eat squatting in windy parking lots. KUSINA NI TESS. Cost-effective Asian comfort food at its finest P:

excerpts: Ordered the LAING (Taro leaves with coconut milk) and the DINIGUAN (pork blood stew) and it was delicious!
laing.author: Shela D.
laing.review:
Ordered the LAING (Taro leaves with coconut milk) and the DINIGUAN (pork blood stew) and it was delicious! Boyfriend got the typical LONGSILOG (marinated pork sausage with garlic friend rice and egg), a true diehard and fan-- haha, friends tried the TOCILOG (marinated pork with garlic friend rice and egg) and the PAKSIW NA TAPA (pork leg, knuckles) and the CHICKEN ADOBO (chicken cooked with soy sauce and vinegar). 

We all left super satisfied and bellies full of delicious food! -- May I add, I've been eating Filipino food all my life, and after 28 years, I think I know what "authentic" Filipino food taste like.

The staff is super friendly and once I started speaking Tagalog, she started called me "iha" which means little daughter. 

Definitely a hidden gem inside of civic center. A lot of their food is pre-cooked so you can order and be on your way! Highly recommend if you're looking for authentic Filipino food!

excerpts: Favorites: laing, mongo beans, lechon kawali and chicken adobo.
laing.author: Javid S.
laing.review:
Authentic filipino food, hella big portions, everything made with lots of love. 

Favorites: laing, mongo beans, lechon kawali and chicken adobo.

excerpts: Laing (Tarrow leaves stewed in coconut milk) was delicious.
Looked like creamed spinach but tasted like thai curry.
Also had delicious pork skewers.
laing.author: Katie A.
laing.review:
Laing (Tarrow leaves stewed in coconut milk) was delicious. Looked like creamed spinach but tasted like thai curry. Also had delicious pork skewers. The menu shifts daily.

Quick, filling, and everyone was so nice.

I'll be back.

excerpts: My favorites are the dinuguan and the Laing.
laing.author: Rae C.
laing.review:
A bit expensive, but the food is really good. My favorites are the dinuguan and the Laing. Can't go wrong with those two. 

Plus, the ladies serving are very helpful and friendly. :)

excerpts: Laing:
Taro leaves cooked in coconut milk.
Very fragrant.
Laing usually has pork and shrimp in it, but the one here was vegetarian.
laing.author: Marti L.
laing.review:
I really want to experience more of the cuisine but Filipino restaurants are so scarce in the city. Then my friend brought me to Kusina Ni Tess which turned out to be a great introductory place!

Kusina Ni Tess is a hole-in-the-wall. Easily missed place with a few tables. All the food was already cooked and kept hot. Normally I'm not a big fan of steam table food, but this was perfect since I was able to study every item. The man behind the counter patiently described the different items and offered me samples. So nice of him!

Garlic Rice: It's not served during lunch. But they had some leftover from breakfast and asked if we mind. We didn't. It was a bit mushy, but still so good! 

Pork Picadillo: Ground pork with potatoes, carrots, and peas. Simple yet flavorful. It was almost stew-like with all the liquid. So good with rice! My favorite!

Pork Adobo: Big chunks of pork stewed together. I wasn't a big fan of this one since the pork had huge pieces of fat on it and wasn't very tender. 

Tortang Tolang: Fried eggplant or eggplant omelet. Basically it's a cooked eggplant, flattened then dipped in egg and fried. Definitely taste the freshness of the eggplant. Yum! 

Laing: Taro leaves cooked in coconut milk. Very fragrant. Laing usually has pork and shrimp in it, but the one here was vegetarian. Rich and heavy, but still tasty! 

I can't really comment on the authenticity or quality since I have no comparison. All I know is we were so satisfied and stuffed and even had leftovers to go. Can't wait to try more! =D

excerpts: I settled on a Pork w/shrimp sauce(?) stew which was awesomely awesome and Laing (Tarrow leaves stewed in coconut milk).
Here is a variant that doesn't look as good as Kusina's did [ http://www.filipino-recipes-lutong-pinoy.com/laing-taro-leaves-stewed-in-coconut-milk.html ]
The Liang was reminiscent of very mild turnip greens (I don't really care for turnip greens) with a Filipino coconut flair.
It was really very good.
laing.author: Clark H.
laing.review:
So, I'm visiting from Texas and peek out my Hotel window from the Hilton Union Square. I spy, "Kusina Ni Tess, Hmmmm." a-yelping I will go. I've been wanting to find an authentic Filipino restaurant to try and this looks tailor-made.

I navigate the sidewalk denizens without issue and enter at Noon on a Tuesday. One man eating, a few more bopping through for plates to go. Overall not busy at all. The owner/partner, I am guessing, greets me with a friendly smile and surmises from my Not-so-San-Fran look that I may need assistance. She proceeds to let me try several items, all of which were tasty flavor explosions. Try that at Chez PooPoos! Yeah, I didn't think so.

I settled on a Pork w/shrimp sauce(?) stew which was awesomely awesome and Laing (Tarrow leaves stewed in coconut milk). Here is a variant that doesn't look as good as Kusina's did [ http://www.filipino-recipes-lutong-pinoy.com/laing-taro-leaves-stewed-in-coconut-milk.html ] The Liang was reminiscent of very mild turnip greens (I don't really care for turnip greens) with a Filipino coconut flair. It was really very good. I ate everything on my plate in no time.

Others have called this a Mom-n-Pop offering and I can agree with that. It definitely feels like you are sitting in a family kitchen while they cook around you. Overall, that ambiance sets the table perfectly for the food you are going to eat. I have little experience with authentic Filipino food, but I can tell you with a high degree of certainty that this is it! How? Because it tastes just like the Filipino sister of Southern comfort food cooked all day and overflowing with 5-gallon-buckets-of-love. 

I had a hard time getting over the $10 limit for Credit Card charges. Yet I am pleasantly full and the Rock concert of flavor lingers like your favorite Pink Floyd song. Awesome food that is easy on the pocketbook in downtown SF!? Whoa.

One line review: This is relaxed, honest food that you won't regret. 

If I can be motivated to get dressed early I'll go try their breakfast offerings in the morning. Considering the alternative $18 bowl of fruit you can purchase from the Hotel - I may have to upgrade that "may" to an "I will absolutely go..."

excerpts: I also ordered the Laing was happy with that.
laing.author: Max W.
laing.review: Really good food. I've been craving Filipino food for a while and was glad I came here. It is kalenderia style with some short order. I was really pleased with selection of foods. I got sinigang pork and was transported back to the Philippines. It wasn't too sour. I also ordered the Laing was happy with that. My wife got chicken adobo which was tasty as well. Got turon or fried banana. Was pleased with it especially since they added jackfruit in it. Would come back again.

excerpts: the garlic rice and laing hit the spot
and i was a convert!
Having eaten many things on the menu, I have to say the laing (taro leaves cooked on coconut milk) and adobo are my favorite.
The adobo is just a perfect amalgamation of soy sauce, ginger, hint of garlic and the coconut milk
just tempers all the spice and works fabulously with the sticky rice served with it.
Add the vegetal and delicious quality of laing and its a fabulous lunch!
laing.author: Sunay P.
laing.review:
I was dragged in here many moons ago ...the neighborhood made me feel mildly unsafe...but also told me that I was probably going to eat something good.  And oh yeah..the garlic rice and laing hit the spot and i was a convert!  Having eaten many things on the menu, I have to say the laing (taro leaves cooked on coconut milk) and adobo are my favorite.  The adobo is just a perfect amalgamation of soy sauce, ginger, hint of garlic and the coconut milk just tempers all the spice and works fabulously with the sticky rice served with it.  Add the vegetal and delicious quality of laing and its a fabulous lunch!

Oh a word of caution : don't try to go there too much later than 3:30 or so,  I have found them running out of food and if you want the full experience, get there for lunch, preferably with 6-7 people and order a bunch of stuff and eat it all!!!

excerpts: Good turon, laing (sp?) and by request, they will make fried adobo.
laing.author: Kris I.
laing.review:
The fam wanted Filipino food, so I yelped the closet thing to Union Square and found this. The area is a little sketch, street parking only, and place is pretty hole-in-the-wall-ish. My dad is a hard man to please, but holy shit, after we started eating, he was content.

The food here is pretty legit to homecooking. Good turon, laing (sp?) and by request, they will make fried adobo. Yes, I said it, FRIED adobo.

Boo on them being out of sinigang when we went on a cold and rainy Saturday. And their lumpia isn't handmade. Also, cash only. But it's definitely still worth a visit for some legit food.

excerpts: I probably go there once every few months and they always have a good variety: laing, adobo, sinigang, corned beef, fried fish, turon, bibingka, kare kare and some others are usually on rotation.
laing.author: HM N.
laing.review: Seems like Kusina ni Tess has gotten better over the years since I first tried them. They've gone through a couple of updates/renovations (as far as I've noticed). Their space is bigger now, still a small place, but they have more tables and chairs where people can sit. Their food selection also seems to have expanded. I probably go there once every few months and they always have a good variety: laing, adobo, sinigang, corned beef, fried fish, turon, bibingka, kare kare and some others are usually on rotation. Their pork sinigang is so good! Not greasy, well-flavored and has balanced portions of meat and veggies. They now accept credit cards too but I usually pay with cash.

excerpts: I went for the chicken adobo and laing (taro root leaves, shrimp, pork, and coconut milk) and both really hit the spot.
Portions are large enough to feed two people or a light dinner for yourself latter.
laing.author: Sylvia D.
laing.review:
Geez, who knew finding a good place for lunch in San Francisco would be so difficult? I figured the city would be littered with good eats, but I'm beginning to think they're located everywhere except within walking distance of my workplace in Union Square. Sorry, but spending double-digits for lunch in a mall food court is unacceptable, even if people hail the San Francisco Shopping Centre as the best mall food court ever. (Note to self: Before accepting a job offer, consider salary, benefits, and local dining options. I'm kidding... Maybe.) 

Kusina Ni Tess, I should've known you would be the answer to my stomach's prayers! I walk by this tiny restaurant on my way to work and the delicious smell of homemade Filipino cuisine wafts through the cold morning air. I turn my head and do a double-take every time as if to check out a hot Filipino guy, but better - hot Filipino fooooood!

I finally had a chance to try Kusina Ni Tess. The food is served a la carte and for a mere $7, I got a white rice and my choice of two sides. The woman there was very nice and offered samples of Filipino dishes I haven't tried before. I went for the chicken adobo and laing (taro root leaves, shrimp, pork, and coconut milk) and both really hit the spot. Portions are large enough to feed two people or a light dinner for yourself latter. Gotta love that!

Four stars for this hole-in-the-wall jewel that won't put a dent in your wallet and feeds you a ton of food just like a typical Filipino mom!

(P.S. Kusina Ni Tess is sandwiched between an adult bookstore/videostore and a liquor store. A perfect storm? I'll let you decide!)

excerpts: I had the Pritong Isda (fried fish - Tilapia) and Laing (taro leaves cooked in a thick and savory coconut milk stew)
- everything was great.
The fish did need a bit of saltiness so adding some Patis (fish sauce) made it perfect - it had a nice delicate flavor.
The Laing was fantastic - a favorite dish of mine that I rarely have - it had so much flavor and I can tell that some excellent spices were added to make it taste amazing.
laing.author: Ken G.
laing.review:
This is a tiny, divey spot with a some very good food with big flavor.

Almost all the food here are prepared and so you can look at all the available items and choose what you'd like to have (Turo-Turo).   I had the Pritong Isda (fried fish - Tilapia) and Laing (taro leaves cooked in a thick and savory coconut milk stew) - everything was great.  The fish did need a bit of saltiness so adding some Patis (fish sauce) made it perfect - it had a nice delicate flavor.  The Laing was fantastic - a favorite dish of mine that I rarely have - it had so much flavor and I can tell that some excellent spices were added to make it taste amazing.  While I wouldn't say it was cheap, it was definitely affordable ($9 for two items and rice).

The place is very small with only 4 tables (1 table for two and 3 tables for four) so I'd suggest not going during peak lunch time hours unless you are planning to take your meal elsewhere...you can also be very friendly and sit next to a stranger if need be.

excerpts: As in, I could've sworn my own Lola was the one stirring up that coconuty-goodness of Laing (taro leaves with coconut milk, and little baby shrimp.)
The pusit (squid), also prepped the way I ate it as a young girl.
The adobo was decent, a little oily for my taste.
But it's too tall an order to top my Mom's, where the chicken gets so tender
it falls off the bone, then you toss it on a pan to get a nice mix of tender and crispy.
(Though, Dad, you've somehow tweaked your timpla of adobo and cooking style, that the difference is nearly imperceptible.)
laing.author: Hanneke F.
laing.review:
FOOD:  Authentic?  Yes.  As in, I could've sworn my own Lola was the one stirring up that coconuty-goodness of Laing (taro leaves with coconut milk, and little baby shrimp.)  The pusit (squid), also prepped the way I ate it as a young girl.  The adobo was decent, a little oily for my taste.  But it's too tall an order to top my Mom's, where the chicken gets so tender it falls off the bone, then you toss it on a pan to get a nice mix of tender and crispy.  (Though, Dad, you've somehow tweaked your timpla of adobo and cooking style, that the difference is nearly imperceptible.)  Turon (saba banana with jackfruit wrapped in lumpia wrapper) was pretty good, glad they didn't skimp on the langka, though I prefer less sugar when they fry it up.

SERVICE:  There's a counter up front where you order, then you seat yourself at the line of small tables along the side.  Aaaalmost like a stand at Market-Market, just in the Tenderloin.  The people are friendly, and there's a mix of people eating there.

PRICE:  Great!

Salamat Tita Tess, and I'll be back!

excerpts: wow, on any given day they would have 4-5 dishes like adobo, sinigang, fried fish, asado, menudo, laing etc. available.
laing.author: mikhael b.
laing.review:
Four stars for:

1. Convenience- located in the heart of Downtown San Francisco.
2. Flavor and quality- not the best Filipino food, but I'd give it a star.
3. Price- very affordable, the owner would also fry your adobo for free if you ask him nicely!
4. Selection- wow, on any given day they would have 4-5 dishes like adobo, sinigang, fried fish, asado, menudo, laing etc. available.

One star negated:

1. Cleanliness!!!!!

excerpts: Laing: Probably my favourite part of my meal.
This is taro leaves cooked in coconut milk.
It tastes like sweet curry, and it melts in your mouth.
Because it's veggies, it feels healthy and it's amazing with rice.
CARBS ON CARBS.
BBQ Pork Skewers:
Well, I really like barbeque and skewers, so no complaints here.

I would've preferred chicken or beef, because I've never really understood what pork tastes like... 
Tinapa: The meat on their fried fish was a little on the dry side, and was hard to eat without really getting our hands dirty (damn flimsy plastic forks), but I really liked how they seasoned/marinated it.
Not too salty and the skin was very crispy.
Beef Stew:
This was really bland, and I had maybe 30% of mine.
I think they were trying to get rid of it, because there were no veggies and no beef, just broth and oil.
laing.author: Katie M.
laing.review:
My manager took me out to lunch for my birthday, and the place we originally wanted to go to had already closed their lunch service (it was 2PM), so we walked around and decided to come in here. 

First of all, let me say that this place isn't very clean and only has 4-5 small tables to sit at, but I'm assuming people get their food to go anyway. It reminds me of small family-run restaurants in Hong Kong, where most customers are regulars and don't mind how run-down it is. They had a television on a Filipino channel, so we got to enjoy some kind of Asian telenovela while we ate. The staff was friendly and did their own thing while we poked and peeked around. 

I think we had just missed the lunch rush here, so they didn't have any noodles left. White rice it is! Carbs on carbs. We decided to do this family-style, and shared:
Pork Adobo: I've only ever had chicken adobo before, and this was a lot less vinegary and more gravy-y than what I remember. The meat was really tender and flavourful, and there wasn't too much fat attached. It was, however, kind of oily but it wasn't too bad.
Laing: Probably my favourite part of my meal. This is taro leaves cooked in coconut milk. It tastes like sweet curry, and it melts in your mouth. Because it's veggies, it feels healthy and it's amazing with rice. CARBS ON CARBS.
BBQ Pork Skewers: Well, I really like barbeque and skewers, so no complaints here. I would've preferred chicken or beef, because I've never really understood what pork tastes like... 
Tinapa: The meat on their fried fish was a little on the dry side, and was hard to eat without really getting our hands dirty (damn flimsy plastic forks), but I really liked how they seasoned/marinated it. Not too salty and the skin was very crispy.
Beef Stew: This was really bland, and I had maybe 30% of mine. I think they were trying to get rid of it, because there were no veggies and no beef, just broth and oil. Nope.

We each got a huge plate of rice, and the portions were huge for one person. Everything came to $23, which is really cheap for how much food we got! I think this was my first time having an authentic Filipino meal, and I will definitely come by again to try more items.

excerpts: The laing we ordered didn't contain any shrimp or meat, just the taro leaves and coconut milk, and was delicious just the same, a very comforting food.
laing.author: Jake m.
laing.review:
The best Filipino food I've ever had to pay for! The selection, which rotates from day to day, is quite diverse and can accommodate a vegetarian satisfactorily, of which I am not. Otherwise, and this is true generally of Filipino cuisine, the meat dishes are the focal points. For sheer variety this place would make me think twice about going home for a Filipino meal. The chicken adobo was flavorful without being overly salty or vinegary, and now that I've discovered that you can request it to be fried, I'll have to try that common variation as well! The laing we ordered didn't contain any shrimp or meat, just the taro leaves and coconut milk, and was delicious just the same, a very comforting food. The dinuguan was, hands down, my favorite part of my meal, and it surprised my companions with its quality, especially after they'd gotten a sample and brief explanation of what it is (pork butt in pork blood). Our meals came with rice and some "soup" which was actually just sinigang broth without the bok choy and beef. 

The location is pretty small and its exterior hardly stands out (despite the bright yellow awning), a real hole-in-the-wall place, but none of this should matter given the delicious and authentic food. And the gentleman (who reigns from Bulacan!) who is frequently at the door is genuinely invested in providing a filling meal. My companions are relatively new to Filipino food and loved all of it. In fact, we bartered over who was going to be taking what after we'd stuffed our faces. 

I've been searching for quality Filipino spots in the city since moving here, and though this is actually my first stop, it'll probably be the primary one. I've yet to try the rellenong bangus or kare-kare, but will be trying them out soon.

excerpts: I also had this with a vegetable dish called Laing.
Laing reminded me of a Thai dish without the spiciness.
It was delicious but it did not compare to the KariKari
The stew dish was very tasty.
It was rich and flavorul.
laing.author: Joe C.
laing.review:
I went there for lunch today and I was floored by Manny having set aside a stew called KarKari based on our brief conversation this past Monday.  I also had this with a vegetable dish called Laing.  Laing reminded me of a Thai dish without the spiciness.  It was delicious but it did not compare to the KariKari  The stew dish was very tasty.  It was rich and flavorul.  I felt like I was eating at somebody's home back in the Philippines.

I was so full that I had to take a fried banana dessert to go that I promised my sister to taste.  I know she will be very jealous when she reads this review! :-)

Best to Manny and the restaurant!

excerpts: So I went with the most talked about Laing:
Taro leaves marinated in coconut milk.
Delicious!
laing.author: Desirea O.
laing.review: I've always passed this place and never had a chance to stop in. How glad I am that I did today. I was feeling a good filipino meal and yelped near Union Square as I was getting into work. All I read were positive and thorough reviews! So, I thought they couldn't fail me! The moment I walked in a welcome greeting came from a friendly man named Manny who asked if this was my first time to visit Kusina Ni Tess. My reply was yes. He then welcome's me and starts off by sending samples my way! I got to try the food before I bought! So I went with the most talked about Laing: Taro leaves marinated in coconut milk. Delicious! As well as the Pork Adobo: A soy sauce and vinegar cooked mixture with pork. Manny then offered to prepare the adobo another way by deep frying the adobo and sampled it for me! He said if you like it prepared this way I will do it for you. But, I preferred the other way. I thought that was extra thoughtful!!! Talk about service. Manny then serves me with the following including a bowl of soup complimentary on the side and free rice refills that I didn't have to go back for with such a generous amount that was served! I had leftovers for my boyfriend to try and he absolutely loved it! Thank you Manny and Tess! I will be back for sure and will bring you business! You all met my delightfullnesss and more!

excerpts: I always order breakfast for lunch and then order pork adobo to save and eat for dinner.
pork adobo.author: Jessica F.
pork adobo.review:
Yum yum yum yum yum!!!  I crave my mom's home cooking all the time and Kusina Ni Tess totally hits the spot and satisfies my need for some authentic and delicious Filipino food.

It's not in the best location (borderline Tenderloin) and it's definitely a little hole in the wall kind of spot, but it's well worth the walk to go grab lunch takeout.  I always over order because all the food makes me so happy that I wish I could eat pounds of it.  I always order breakfast for lunch and then order pork adobo to save and eat for dinner.  Longsilog, garlic rice with an extra fried egg, and a side of lumpia.  Extra vinegar on the side please.  I'm drooling while I type this and now need to plan my next visit. 

Overall- great food, prices, and people.

excerpts: The  pork adobo is literally God sent.
pork adobo.author: Lauren A.
pork adobo.review: Probably the most wholesome place I've been to. Manny is literally the SWEETEST and let us try everything before ordering. Everything is freshly cooked and I highly recommend everything haha. Garlic rice is tender and flavorful. The turon is crisp and chewy. The  pork adobo is literally God sent.

excerpts: I got small pork adobo, small dinuguan, small lechon.
Total was $21.
A bit pricey frankly, but the food itself is very good.
The adobo and dinuguan is tender and flavorful.
The Lechon is deep fried a second time to warm it up, making it very crispy and flavorful.
I took it all home
and I really wish I stayed at the restaurant to eat it
The second time I came back, I got a medium size of pork adobo and small lechon plus a scoop of rice.
I definitely could have gotten a small adobo instead because the medium was HUGE.
pork adobo.author: edward k.
pork adobo.review:
EAT-IN DO NOT TAKE OUT IF YOU CAN HELP IT!!!!! The reason I say this is because the portions are easily 1.5x-2x if you eat in house.

Now on to the food. The first the I came. I got small pork adobo, small dinuguan, small lechon. Total was $21. A bit pricey frankly, but the food itself is very good. The adobo and dinuguan is tender and flavorful. The Lechon is deep fried a second time to warm it up, making it very crispy and flavorful. I took it all home and I really wish I stayed at the restaurant to eat it because like I said... portions.

The second time I came back, I got a medium size of pork adobo and small lechon plus a scoop of rice. $18. I definitely could have gotten a small adobo instead because the medium was HUGE.  The ladies are very generous with the portions when you eat in and its totally worth it.

Overall, the food is very good. Prices could be a bit cheaper. I've been to much cheaper filipino joints but this is the best the city has in this area.

excerpts: Pork Adobo: Big chunks of pork stewed together.
pork adobo.author: Marti L.
pork adobo.review:
I really want to experience more of the cuisine but Filipino restaurants are so scarce in the city. Then my friend brought me to Kusina Ni Tess which turned out to be a great introductory place!

Kusina Ni Tess is a hole-in-the-wall. Easily missed place with a few tables. All the food was already cooked and kept hot. Normally I'm not a big fan of steam table food, but this was perfect since I was able to study every item. The man behind the counter patiently described the different items and offered me samples. So nice of him!

Garlic Rice: It's not served during lunch. But they had some leftover from breakfast and asked if we mind. We didn't. It was a bit mushy, but still so good! 

Pork Picadillo: Ground pork with potatoes, carrots, and peas. Simple yet flavorful. It was almost stew-like with all the liquid. So good with rice! My favorite!

Pork Adobo: Big chunks of pork stewed together. I wasn't a big fan of this one since the pork had huge pieces of fat on it and wasn't very tender. 

Tortang Tolang: Fried eggplant or eggplant omelet. Basically it's a cooked eggplant, flattened then dipped in egg and fried. Definitely taste the freshness of the eggplant. Yum! 

Laing: Taro leaves cooked in coconut milk. Very fragrant. Laing usually has pork and shrimp in it, but the one here was vegetarian. Rich and heavy, but still tasty! 

I can't really comment on the authenticity or quality since I have no comparison. All I know is we were so satisfied and stuffed and even had leftovers to go. Can't wait to try more! =D

excerpts: I had the pork adobo with rice.
Lots of flavor packed into this dish, very good.
Lady serving food was very nice and let me try samples.
Reasonable prices.
pork adobo.author: Joe H.
pork adobo.review: I had the pork adobo with rice. Lots of flavor packed into this dish, very good. Lady serving food was very nice and let me try samples. Reasonable prices.

excerpts: Also got my delivery order wrong gave me pork adobo instead of what I ordered chicken adobo.
Would eat here again with a few adjustments on what to order.
pork adobo.author: Jay H.
pork adobo.review: Most the food is good got the Longansilog and Tosilog egg was cooked well.  The Garlic fried rice like others have said tasted stale.  Way to hard and dry.  Should have just gotten steam rice instead with the silogs.  Also got my delivery order wrong gave me pork adobo instead of what I ordered chicken adobo.  Would eat here again with a few adjustments on what to order.

excerpts: Pork adobo was pretty good with the fatty chunks of pork just melting into the vinegary sauce.
Great with a hit of more vinegar even.
pork adobo.author: Kevin L.
pork adobo.review:
For $5, you can get a heaping pile of rice with a little tublet of adobo, which comes in chicken, beef, or pork forms. Pork adobo was pretty good with the fatty chunks of pork just melting into the vinegary sauce. Great with a hit of more vinegar even. Beef stew comes with carrots and potatoes, which would have been nice for some contrast. 

We snagged a fried banana and jackfruit roll for a buck something before leaving. Even cold, the sugar crackled coating was tasty.

Menu doesn't have explanations of what things are, but the ladies behind the counter were super friendly about us hemming and hawing about what to get.

excerpts: 10 bucks gets you a huge portion of pork adobo ( amazing ) with rice and lumpia.
Found my new dig!!
( Cash Only )
pork adobo.author: natasha g.
pork adobo.review:
So i have been looking for a great filipino restaurant in SF, well i found it. While yes i am a gringo i have traveled to the Philippines a few times and this place is the real deal. 10 bucks gets you a huge portion of pork adobo ( amazing ) with rice and lumpia.
Found my new dig!!  ( Cash Only )

excerpts: Pork Adobo:
Tender pieces of well marinated pork belly with the melt in your mouth fat still attached.
You should encourage your server to pour extra of that not-too-vinegary adobo sauce on the rice since such a combination is amazing.
pork adobo.author: Adam B.
pork adobo.review:
Michelle Obama should launch her crusade against obesity here!  Enormously huge portions, fat intensive mains and enough white rice to feed a bayan.  What a worthwhile indulgence!!!  I find that I can squeeze 3-4 work lunches from only 2 of the 2-item combination plates.

Pork Adobo: Tender pieces of well marinated pork belly with the melt in your mouth fat still attached.  You should encourage your server to pour extra of that not-too-vinegary adobo sauce on the rice since such a combination is amazing.  Would have been nice if a few pieces were fried for texture contrast, but still great as is.

Pancit: They used the rice vermicelli noodles as opposed to the canton egg noodles.  Packed with flavor.  Great job on making the vegetables (carrots, onions, string beans) a firm, yet not raw texture, and daintily sliced.

Caldereta: Very tender despite being a stew quality cut of beef.  The carrots are just there.  The potatoes seem a bit undercooked.  I used the onion vinegar sauce to add a little personality to this humble dish.

Giniling na Baboy: Reminds me of Indian/Pakistani keema with the peas and diced veggies (carrots, potatoes, green peppers).  Mixes perfectly with the rice as it can disburse evenly on top of the individual grains.

Banana Spring Roll: We've pretty much had this at any Asian restaurant which strives to offer a dessert besides orange slices.  The spin here is a crunchy sugar coating layer on top of the already fried roll skin.  It works, it's tasty.  The banana inside could stand to be a tad fresher though.

excerpts: : she offered samples of three different dishes, and I ended up getting a combo plate of two (the pork adobo and one other whose name escapes me).
Great food, friendly people, highly recommended.
pork adobo.author: Darius K.
pork adobo.review: Wonderful little restaurant. I came in not knowing anything about Filipino food, and it was probably pretty clear to the woman behind the counter: she offered samples of three different dishes, and I ended up getting a combo plate of two (the pork adobo and one other whose name escapes me). Great food, friendly people, highly recommended.

excerpts: Yesterday, I tried the Pancit Bihon & Pork Adobo.
Both dishes were delicious.
I definitely will be coming back when I yearn for Filipino food but can't visit Mom.
pork adobo.author: James R.
pork adobo.review:
I (James) think the reason why Filipino restaurants have not proliferated like Chinese, Thai or other Asian restaurants is that we Filipinos are very picky when it comes to our native cuisine.  If it doesn't taste as Mom cooked it, then it's not the same.

Kusina Ni Tess is as close as it gets to Mom's Filipino home cooking.  Yesterday, I tried the Pancit Bihon & Pork Adobo. Both dishes were delicious.  I definitely will be coming back when I yearn for Filipino food but can't visit Mom.  The owner/cook, Manny, is very friendly and will allow you to sample before you order.

For what this hole in the wall lacks in decor, it's made up by the flavors of the food and the hospitality of the owner.  You definitely get value for your money.  And for those who say a meal is not meal unless you have white steamed rice, I got a big plate of rice when I ordered the adobo.

excerpts: I have also eaten chicken and pork adobo, both saucy and peppery vinegary.
The complimentary broth they give you to start is a little bland and strange but Filipino friends say it tastes just right.
Good choice of veggies each time
, I've had the bitter melon and the winter melon.
Prices are great
and I covet one of those banana egg rolls but have yet to indulge.
pork adobo.author: Maya H.
pork adobo.review: I've eaten here twice and was great each time.  It is the most tender pork skewers ever.  They cook small batches of food right in the front so you know its fresh when you order it.  I have also eaten chicken and pork adobo, both saucy and peppery vinegary.  The complimentary broth they give you to start is a little bland and strange but Filipino friends say it tastes just right.  Good choice of veggies each time, I've had the bitter melon and the winter melon.  Prices are great and I covet one of those banana egg rolls but have yet to indulge.

excerpts:
We decided to do this family-style, and shared:
Pork Adobo: I've only ever had chicken adobo before, and this was a lot less vinegary and more gravy-y than what I remember.
The meat was really tender and flavourful, and there wasn't too much fat attached.
It was, however, kind of oily
but it wasn't too bad.
pork adobo.author: Katie M.
pork adobo.review:
My manager took me out to lunch for my birthday, and the place we originally wanted to go to had already closed their lunch service (it was 2PM), so we walked around and decided to come in here. 

First of all, let me say that this place isn't very clean and only has 4-5 small tables to sit at, but I'm assuming people get their food to go anyway. It reminds me of small family-run restaurants in Hong Kong, where most customers are regulars and don't mind how run-down it is. They had a television on a Filipino channel, so we got to enjoy some kind of Asian telenovela while we ate. The staff was friendly and did their own thing while we poked and peeked around. 

I think we had just missed the lunch rush here, so they didn't have any noodles left. White rice it is! Carbs on carbs. We decided to do this family-style, and shared:
Pork Adobo: I've only ever had chicken adobo before, and this was a lot less vinegary and more gravy-y than what I remember. The meat was really tender and flavourful, and there wasn't too much fat attached. It was, however, kind of oily but it wasn't too bad.
Laing: Probably my favourite part of my meal. This is taro leaves cooked in coconut milk. It tastes like sweet curry, and it melts in your mouth. Because it's veggies, it feels healthy and it's amazing with rice. CARBS ON CARBS.
BBQ Pork Skewers: Well, I really like barbeque and skewers, so no complaints here. I would've preferred chicken or beef, because I've never really understood what pork tastes like... 
Tinapa: The meat on their fried fish was a little on the dry side, and was hard to eat without really getting our hands dirty (damn flimsy plastic forks), but I really liked how they seasoned/marinated it. Not too salty and the skin was very crispy.
Beef Stew: This was really bland, and I had maybe 30% of mine. I think they were trying to get rid of it, because there were no veggies and no beef, just broth and oil. Nope.

We each got a huge plate of rice, and the portions were huge for one person. Everything came to $23, which is really cheap for how much food we got! I think this was my first time having an authentic Filipino meal, and I will definitely come by again to try more items.

excerpts: I had the pork adobo (YUMMMM) with white rice, and when I asked them not to give me too many fatty pieces, they were OK about it!
And it's true- they do give huge portions, but I am a glutton, and I devoured all of it.
They have other options too, such as fried fish, chicken dishes, stews, and if you don't know, you can point or just ask (they will clarify).
The cook/server (stocky guy) was so friendly.
I went 2 days in a row and he remembered me!
They also make/sell some sweets there.
pork adobo.author: Graciete L.
pork adobo.review: love it! I was in town for a conference @ the Hilton across the street and stumbled upon this fabulous eatery. The place is a bit run down.. okay hole in the wall, but it has a nice homey feel (like I'm in Southeast Asia!) and it's served cafeteria style. It's nothing fancy, but the prices were decent ($7-9). I had the pork adobo (YUMMMM) with white rice, and when I asked them not to give me too many fatty pieces, they were OK about it! And it's true- they do give huge portions, but I am a glutton, and I devoured all of it. They have other options too, such as fried fish, chicken dishes, stews, and if you don't know, you can point or just ask (they will clarify). The cook/server (stocky guy) was so friendly. I went 2 days in a row and he remembered me! They also make/sell some sweets there.

excerpts: I was familiar with was adobo and lumpia, so I ordered pork adobo and lumpia.
I asked her what else was good
and she started giving me tastes.
Of everything.
(there was no one else in the restaurant at the time).
So I can say that

: the taro root in coconut milk is something you gotta try; the orange noodles cooked in cream of mushroom soup, mashed tofu and egg are delish; the chicken something and vegetables are good, the lumpia is so good, the stuff with shrimp paste is yummy.
They have BBQ pork on a stick.
Let me be clear:  BBQ.
Pork.
On a stick.
And, she answered every single question (and I asked a lot) about what stuff was.
So:  very good, inexpensive food and service with more than a smile - Kusina Ni Tess is a winner.
Did I mention the BBQ pork on a stick?
pork adobo.author: Cookie C.
pork adobo.review: The nicest, friendliest woman in San Francisco works at Kusina Ni Tess.  I was working late for a conference, and ran out to get some food here before it closed.  I had tried on two prior occasions (one a year ago) to try the food here, and this was my first successful time.  The only Filipino food I was familiar with was adobo and lumpia, so I ordered pork adobo and lumpia.  I asked her what else was good and she started giving me tastes.  Of everything. (there was no one else in the restaurant at the time).  So I can say that: the taro root in coconut milk is something you gotta try; the orange noodles cooked in cream of mushroom soup, mashed tofu and egg are delish; the chicken something and vegetables are good, the lumpia is so good, the stuff with shrimp paste is yummy.  They have BBQ pork on a stick.  Let me be clear:  BBQ. Pork. On a stick. And, she answered every single question (and I asked a lot) about what stuff was.  So:  very good, inexpensive food and service with more than a smile - Kusina Ni Tess is a winner.  Did I mention the BBQ pork on a stick?

excerpts: As well as the Pork Adobo:
A soy sauce and vinegar cooked mixture with pork.
Manny then offered to prepare the adobo another way by deep frying the adobo and sampled it for me!
He said if you like it prepared this way I will do it for you.
But, I preferred the other way.
I thought that was extra thoughtful!!!
Talk about service.
Manny then serves me with the following including a bowl of soup complimentary on the side and free rice refills that I didn't have to go back for with such a generous amount that was served!
I had leftovers for my boyfriend to try and he absolutely loved it!
Thank you Manny and Tess!
I will be back for sure and will bring you business!
You all met my delightfullnesss and more!
pork adobo.author: Desirea O.
pork adobo.review: I've always passed this place and never had a chance to stop in. How glad I am that I did today. I was feeling a good filipino meal and yelped near Union Square as I was getting into work. All I read were positive and thorough reviews! So, I thought they couldn't fail me! The moment I walked in a welcome greeting came from a friendly man named Manny who asked if this was my first time to visit Kusina Ni Tess. My reply was yes. He then welcome's me and starts off by sending samples my way! I got to try the food before I bought! So I went with the most talked about Laing: Taro leaves marinated in coconut milk. Delicious! As well as the Pork Adobo: A soy sauce and vinegar cooked mixture with pork. Manny then offered to prepare the adobo another way by deep frying the adobo and sampled it for me! He said if you like it prepared this way I will do it for you. But, I preferred the other way. I thought that was extra thoughtful!!! Talk about service. Manny then serves me with the following including a bowl of soup complimentary on the side and free rice refills that I didn't have to go back for with such a generous amount that was served! I had leftovers for my boyfriend to try and he absolutely loved it! Thank you Manny and Tess! I will be back for sure and will bring you business! You all met my delightfullnesss and more!

excerpts: Chicken and pork adobo, fried tilapia fish, dinaguan ("chocolate meat"), calderada (beef, ox-tail), chicken tinola (soup), sinigang na baboy (pork) or isda (fish) to name a few of the main dishes.
The menu varies from day to day, but they often have 6-8 mains to choose from.
Lumpia is sometimes on the menu, and WE ALL LOVE LUMPIA!!
pork adobo.author: Barbie D.
pork adobo.review:
Tes's Kitchen is definitely a hidden gem on the outskirts of the TL. Having worked in the Union Square area and now downtown, this is the closest you're going to get to authentic Filipino food where you don't have to venture too deep into cracky territory.

Chicken and pork adobo, fried tilapia fish, dinaguan ("chocolate meat"), calderada (beef, ox-tail), chicken tinola (soup), sinigang na baboy (pork) or isda (fish) to name a few of the main dishes. The menu varies from day to day, but they often have 6-8 mains to choose from. Lumpia is sometimes on the menu, and WE ALL LOVE LUMPIA!! Just today they had freshly made turon (fried wrapped banana, glazed with sticky sugar)....Scrumptious!! You can get a huge plate of rice and a main dish for $6 even. Add turon or lumpia for another $1, or a tall cocounut or cantelope juice for $1-1.50, for a total of less than $9! That's a deal.

Although Tes' Kitchen may not have the expansive selection as the more commercial restaurants like Goldilocks (closest one is in the Excelsior District) or your nearby Jolli Bee's (McDonald's of the Philippines), but this place is simple, more local, and in my opinion authentic.

It's a small hole in the wall, so it doesn't fit many. Customers are your usual nearby workers from adjacent hotels or local community members. Don't expect ambiance either, you can get that in a ritzy hotel restaurant by the Square. But they do speak ENGLISH for all you non-fluent Tagalog speakers like me.

Hours?? I don't know, I've only come here for lunch the past few years. Whenever I get that crave, and mom's place is too far for lunch, I come to Auntie Tes'.

excerpts: Had the pork adobo twice and the beef stew over steam rice and was quite pleased.
The portions are quite big, they even offered  a bowl of soup too.
I don't mind fish being fry right there because you know it is freshly cooked.
I'm trying the fried fish next time.
The staff is courteous.
Reasonable prices, main dishes are either $6 or $7, but
I rather  eat here than having a burger from Burger King or Carl's Jr.
My only complaint is that the volume on the TV way too high.
Non Philippine reviewer, but enjoy the cuisine.
pork adobo.author: Hum V.
pork adobo.review: I worked about 4 blocks away and sometimes I feel like having Filipino food, so what a surprise that I discovered this small gem in the area. I've been there 3 times during already. Had the pork adobo twice and the beef stew over steam rice and was quite pleased.The portions are quite big, they even offered  a bowl of soup too. I don't mind fish being fry right there because you know it is freshly cooked.  I'm trying the fried fish next time. The staff is courteous. Reasonable prices, main dishes are either $6 or $7, but  I rather  eat here than having a burger from Burger King or Carl's Jr. My only complaint is that the volume on the TV way too high. Non Philippine reviewer, but enjoy the cuisine.

excerpts: So many Filipino food places put pork in the Pancit, put pork in the Mongo and often pinakbit, and they don't have enough chicken or vegetarian options.
There always is something that I can eat here even though I don't eat pork and beef and get my Filipino food fix.
mongo.author: Louise K.
mongo.review: What I like about this down home Filipino food spot is that they do not put pork in everything... So many Filipino food places put pork in the Pancit, put pork in the Mongo and often pinakbit, and they don't have enough chicken or vegetarian options. There always is something that I can eat here even though I don't eat pork and beef and get my Filipino food fix.

excerpts: I ended up with Chicken Adobo, the mung beans stew (mongo), a stewed pork (i think it was binagoongan) ... and taro leaves in coconut milk - all in small sizes - along in with a side of rice.
so so so yummy.
For ME, everything hit the spot and took me 'home' to my childhood.
I was pleasantly surprised at the flavours and quality.
Perhaps it was because I was hungry, perhaps because it was just that good.
mongo.author: Leslie R.
mongo.review:
So I was at the Hilton and wanted a quick bite, and found that Kusina Ni Tess was right across the street!!  I wanted a quick meal, so I went through Eat24, placed an order for pick-up and waited a bit.  I guess I should have looked at the photos, to better understand that it's essentially a steam plate restaurant so it wasn't necessary to do that.   Anyway - when I got there, they didn't receive the Eat24 order, talked about how they don't get the order, but that it would be on Maria's cell phone, etc etc.  Also more importantly, of the 4 things I ordered and paid for, 2 of the items were not available that day - which, again - had I looked, is totally understandable when knowing it's a steam plate / to go type of place.

Rather than go through the process of calling Maria and deal with the order, I showed them my receipt, and then I was able to substitute items to make up the same totals.   The ladies in there were super accommodating and helpful (even though I was a bit disappointed that I cldn't have 2 items I had been craving on my walk over).  Luckily I'm a glutton, and love to eat - so there were plenty of other options.  

While not filipina myself, I grew up in Asia, and had home cooking at home often.  I ended up with Chicken Adobo, the mung beans stew (mongo), a stewed pork (i think it was binagoongan) ... and taro leaves in coconut milk - all in small sizes - along in with a side of rice.  so so so yummy.  For ME, everything hit the spot and took me 'home' to my childhood.  I was pleasantly surprised at the flavours and quality.  Perhaps it was because I was hungry, perhaps because it was just that good.  Hard to tell.  

Neighbourhood is a bit sketchy - some might not feel 'comfortable' eating in the restaurant, though there is seating.  I took mine to go and ate in my room - and would likely have preferred to do that, simply because my room was more comfortable.

Anyway - worth a shot.  Definitely don't bother ordering online in advance. There will not be a long wait, as it's pretty much ready to serve - and you never know what will still be available at any given time.

Enjoy!

excerpts: Favorites: laing, mongo beans, lechon kawali and chicken adobo.
mongo.author: Javid S.
mongo.review:
Authentic filipino food, hella big portions, everything made with lots of love. 

Favorites: laing, mongo beans, lechon kawali and chicken adobo.

excerpts: Noticing my small frame and apprehension to the mongo-load of rice she wanted to dish me, she conceeded to providing a smaller portion.
I have never really eaten much Filipino food and found it to be greasy and mysterious, but all around very tasty.
I tried the purple string beans with chunks of pork fat paired with a type of creamed spinach in sweet coconut milk.
I also had two small bowls of the peppered beef broth which was excellent, but a littly salty.
Atmosphere was good, but I had wished it was slightly cleaner.
My co-worker had two meat dishes, one chicken curry and the other was an asian style meatloaf.
mongo.author: Nicole S.
mongo.review:
My co-worker and I are doing a pan-Asian lunch tour of San Francisco and today we drew "Philippines" from the box of crinkled up post-it notes bearing the names of 12 Asian countries.

Well, San Francisco, despite swimming in Asian Culture is lacking any real consortium of Filipino cuisine. Note to self.

We found Kusina Ni Tess after some quick Yelping and I would say that most of these reviews are pretty accurate. Very homestyle - Tess was very accomodating and even let me try a few of the dishes before I picked my lunch platter. Noticing my small frame and apprehension to the mongo-load of rice she wanted to dish me, she conceeded to providing a smaller portion. I have never really eaten much Filipino food and found it to be greasy and mysterious, but all around very tasty. I tried the purple string beans with chunks of pork fat paired with a type of creamed spinach in sweet coconut milk. I also had two small bowls of the peppered beef broth which was excellent, but a littly salty. Atmosphere was good, but I had wished it was slightly cleaner. My co-worker had two meat dishes, one chicken curry and the other was an asian style meatloaf. She didn't feel too great afterwards, but I think it was because she ate too much of the fried banana wrapped in lumpia skin for dessert.

All in all, I liked the experience but will probably not return unless they tidy up a bit. The recipes were good and definitely unique. The flavors reminded me of a blend between southern Chinese cuisine and Indian.
